Traveling definitely presents some unique challenges to getting a workout in. Best-case scenarios (finding a great facility, having plenty of time, etc, etc) are rare, and much more often you're left to make-do with whatever you can find. In this case, Coach Will found a play structure and a bench on a run while traveling, and went to work. If you could use a little inspiration, check out our FREE Travel Workout Trail Guide ebook on our website (link in our profile).

The RKC Plank. One of our favorite moves. It is a deceptively simple exercise, and we *only* ask you to hold each Plank for 10 seconds. But ask any of our clients, when you get these suckers dialed in, 10 secs is all you need. 
Set up is key! Follow these steps: -
#
start on your forearms and knees, with elbows under armpits -sink your chest towards the floor and allow your shoulder blades to slide towards your spine, then do the opposite! Press your forearms into the floor and drive your shoulder blades wide, so your shoulders feel engaged and active. 
#
brace your abs 
#
step the feet back one at a time, 
making a mini down dog 
#
keeping abs braced, squeeze your quads (to pull up on your knee caps), and then squeeze your glutes to bring the hips down towards the floor, into alignment with your shoulders 
#
dig your elbows into the floor in order to pull your elbows towards your toes, while pulling your toes towards your elbows 
#
hold 10 sec. breathe. .
.
Your goal is total body tension! This should be the hardest 10 secs of your day. We recommend doing a set of three 10sec holds, with 5-10 secs rest in between
.
.
.
.
.
#thefitnessalchemists #musclesandmindfulness #fitnessisforeveryone #thefitnessalchemists #plank #rkcplank #coreworkouts #functionaltraining #efficiency @hannahhusband thanks for the videography @msypa

The ability to re-focus is one worth cultivating. It is inevitable that something along your journey will not go according to plan (in this sequence, my first foot wrap goes awry, and then Later my top foot gets stuck as I'm trying to bend my bottom leg) but because I've been working on calming my mind and refocusing on the task at hand, I made it through to the end of the sequence. 
How do you cultivate focus? What has worked well for you? How do you get back on track? .
.
.
.

Gotta love an EMOM workout! Put 12 minutes on the clock. Every Minute On The Minute (#EMOM) alternate between two exercises: -Deadlift x 2
-Sled push 30ft
Rest the remainder of the minute. You should get in 6 rounds of both exercises! Big shout out to Nirav and Diana for letting me video them, and cracking jokes the whole time! .

@hunterfitness is a real inspiration, and not necessarily because of his crazy joint range. . . . . . . .
. "Yoga. I enjoy it very much. But I don't love it. I don't consider myself a true yogi. I don't spend hours a week practicing. I don't want to be disrespectful to all the yogi's I know who put their heart into their practice. ð»
I do it because it's a body weight practice to me. I like to treat it as ART. My body IS a piece of art. And yoga is one of my canvases of choice. ð»
I like to see what kind of shapes I can bend and twist into for fun. For photos. To a true yogi- that's probably a disgrace. The fact that I don't take it seriously. ð»
I've always been flexible- but it's only been the last few years that I really learned to control my ROM and improve mobility.
ð»
I owe almost all of my mobility education to the FRC mobility specialist certification via @drandreospina . Thanks to this knowledge- I have learned to control the ROM I've had for years but had no ability to use, and then continue to improve ROM  as well. Some of my best yoga poses were accomplished thanks to applying FRC principles to my warm ups getting ready for photos. Take this photo for example- Something like this- an extreme ROM- I don't "do yoga" to get ready for this stuff. I pull out the big guns and aggressively work on my ROM via the principles taught at FRC to open up range that was not accessible before. ð»"
.
.
.
#controlyourself #frc #funtionalanatomy #fitnessisforeveryone #fitness #fitfam #thefitnessalchemists

Happy Monday, folks! It can be tempting, especially when we've had a super fun weekend, to hit the gym really hard on Monday in an attempt to "make up" any lost ground. 
This is dangerous. 
If you over do it on Monday, it could mean you're so sore that you blow off working out for several days, if not the whole week, and the cycle continues. 
Better to leave some in the tank for tomorrow's training session, than to over extend today. 
You can always do more tomorrow!
.
.
.
.
.
.
#thefitnessalchemists #mondaymotivation #progressnotperfection #strengthofpurpose #fitfam #fitnessisforeveryone #gymnasticsbodies

Hip CARs! It's a love/hate relationship... ...According to most of our clients. ð

The hip is a ball in socket joint, and should posses an incredible range of motion (think dancers or karate masters). While we don't need that kind of elite mobility to be regular humans, maintaining functional hip mobility plays a key role in good life. When the hips lack mobility, the low back is in trouble. Be sure to move your hips in their fullest range of motion (biggest circle) every day. ð

Just make sure the spine doesn't jump in on the party. It's a hipster party. Hip movement only! (Coach @hannahhusband shows hip CARs in real time.)

Do you have sticky scaps?

The scapula (shoulder blades) are unique because they only have ONE bony attachment. Most bones have two. This gives them incredible range of motion, but also means that the muscles surrounding them need to be strong, supple and in balance with each other. â¯ï¸
You should be able to move your scaps in all of these ways:
â¬ï¸ elevation
â¬ï¸ depression
â¡ï¸â¬ï¸ retraction
â¬ï¸â¡ï¸ protraction
âï¸ upward rotation
âï¸ downward rotation 
Give it a try and see how smooth or sticky these ranges of motion are. Grease and improve your ROM with scapular CARs! ð
Coach @hannahhusband shows her morning scapular CARs here in real time. With serious face. ð¶
Because happy scaps require solemn expressions. ð

Coach @welew_  does some active hip flexion holds with knee hinges while watching TV! The greatest thing about mobility training imho? You can do it ANYWHERE. ANYTIME. 
Even if you do little bits here and there. It's all ð°in the bank. ð
Have you made any deposits today?

How do you know where your body is in space? 
#
Itâs not easy. The body prefers to follow the path of least resistance. And the body is really good at convincing you itâs doing the thing, when in fact it is doing a poor approximation of the thing. 
#
This is why coaching is essential. We all need some external observation and #feedback to make sure we are, in fact, doing the thing. 
# 
Hereâs our awesome client @schreink setting up in the quadruped position (for some Hip CARs, of course). The top picture is what feels like a neutral spine to Karen. The bottom picture feels to Karen like she is rounded, like a cat stretch! But notice that she is, in fact, neutral, and now her scapula are on her rib cage, rather than winging up. 
#
Trusting your coach is also key here, because she has to believe me instead of her own feeling of where her body is in space. Until slowly but surely, we re-map. 
#
Thank you for your trust & commitment, Karen! We love having you as part of the Fitness Alchemists fam. .
.
.
.
.
.
.
#proprioception #feedback #coaching #clientspotlight #quadruped #hipCARs #scapula #mindset #smallgrouptraining #mobility #strength #strengthtraining #wednesdaywisdom #happyhumpday #oakland #thefitnessalchemists #forgingresilienthumans

Here's how you can check if your program is working for you:
- Are you getting better at what matters?
- Does your body feel mostly good, most of the time?
- Each time you move intentionally (hiking, lifting weights, play with your kids, play a sport, "exercise"), do you look forward to discovering how your body will respond?
ð¤¸

Make sure the toes (all 5) and the heel stay planted, and the arch of the foot actively lifted, throughout your range of motion.

Quick PSA about WHY @hannahhusband and I started this here company...
-
Resilience /rÉËzilyÉns/: the capacity to recover quickly from difficulties; toughness
-
In the game of life, you will confront challenges. And when you do, your ability to overcome them will come down to how well you can weather that particular storm. How well you can persevere and stay focused on YOUR guiding principles.  How resilient you are.
-
How do you cultivate resilience? Well, you can start with your own, physical body, the vehicle that will carry you through your personal adventure. You can work on controlling that body, making it more resistant to injury, and stronger at the tasks that YOU need, for YOUR life.
-
We've found that this process--of progressively guiding the body to adapt toward a more effective version of YOU--is a perfect analogy for building resilience generally. Control what you can, acknowledge your own weakness, and focus on what's important, for YOU. Work on it.
-
Here's to your resilience.
@welew_

@peakbodyintegration challenged us to try the 
@zhealth_performance #aroundtheworld challenge, which is as follows:
-
Take a light weight.
-
Stand on one leg and with the opposing arm hit forward center, up and right, right, back right and straight back.
-
Repeat to come back.
-
Go slow to win the race. -

It all started with my feet.
-â¢-
One of the foundations of human physiology is Wolffs Law, which says âbone in a healthy person or animal will adapt to the loads under which it is placed.â I think of it as the very definition of common sense, written in our cells: only the stuff that you strain will change, and it will change only in the *way* that you strain it.
-â¢-
In the winter of 2008, I was training for a marathon. I ended up bitting off more than I could chew (upping my mileage too fast), and  hurt myself. Looking around for options, I started reading about these crazy people running in bare feet. More than the culture shock of âlook ma! No shoes!â, I was mighty curious as to how their feet didnât just...explode. I meanâhere I was, 19 years old, hobbled, unable to walkâlet alone runâin $100 shoes. And they were grinning and trail running, in the snow, in their bare feet. I had to figure what these folks were doing different.
-â¢-
Now, almost a decade later, reading and running and rotating (#cars), I have a clearer picture. But it mostly boils down to this: expose yourself to the forces that you want to master. Let them stress you, push you, mold you. Do it slowly, and with eyes wide open. But donât hide from those forces.
-â¢-

A staple of the @functionalrangeconditioning @kinstretch universe of mobility concepts (each worth a thousand âexercisesâ): the Kinetic Stretch.
-â¢-
A Kinetic Stretch is a stretch you slowly give yourselfâthis camera is sped up 5xâby using the shrinking side of the joint (my shin, here) to âpullâ yourself into a stretch. Once you canât go any further, you pause, shift your attention/tension ð to the other side of the joint (where youâd *feel* the stretch) and âpushâ yourself out of the stretch.
-â¢-
Filmed this vid for a distance coaching client who, after years of dancing had lost her faith in her ankles. This Kinetic Stretch setup is one of my favorite ways to get ankles to work better (meaning stronger, more range of motion, and generally, contributing a positive attitude to the rest of your body ð). But I could just as well use it to clean up my hips, or my neck, or my _____ (insert cranky joint here). Or as @drandreospina says, it just helps me, âMake shit work nice.â
-â¢-
Let me know if you need help with your mobility! We are now offering remote mobility coaching (follow @thefitnessalchemists for more info in coming weeks) but the first wave of clients have been loving it. Do you even rotate your thoracic, bro?
â 
Hereâs my favorite set up for Thoracic CARs aka mobilizing your stiff upper back.
â 
The upper back (roughly above your belly button) is where the MOST movement should occur.
â 
The lower back has much less capacity to move - especially to rotate.
â 
However, if you are missing movement capacity in your upper back, as is the case for many of us who spend too many hours on computers and hunched over cell phones, your lower back will pick up the slack.
â 
Anytime a part of your body is picking up slack for another part that isnât doing its proper job, things are bound to go awry.
â 
Take some time to restore movement to your upper back so that it can take over itâs rightful duties: â 
ð¸flexion (rounding forward)
ð¸rotation (twist your t shirt logo to face the side)
ð¸lateral flexion (side bend or side crunch)
ð¸extension (lift your chest - get tall!) â 
Follow along with me in this video (I show 1 rep before IG cuts me off, you should do 2 or 3, then repeat it on the other side.)
â 
We work on gems like this in my #kinstretch class every week. â 

Spinal segmentation is so important! â 
And modeled beautifully here by @whittlesjh who wore the perfect hoodie for the occasion ð
â 
If you do nothing else for your body daily, please do this:
â 
â¡ï¸get on your hands and knees
â¡ï¸try to move slowly through each segment of your spine from tail to head.
â¡ï¸Make a round shape (spinal flexion) then a sway back shape (spinal extension)
â¡ï¸go slow so that you can take a muscular inventory of your spine
â 
We need to be able to move each vertebrae in relation to the next in order to absorb force along the whole spine.
â 
If only a few places in our spine have the ability to move, too much force is driven into those junctions.
â 
A strong spine is a mobile spine is a healthy spine!
â 
Tap for sound to hear coach @hannahhusband cue you through the exercise.

The Mat Effect: the mat can âopen a neurological windowâ in which for at least a few minutes, new movement patterns can emerge. The mat does not âteachâ the horse to do bigger and/or more fluid movements, it opens the possibility. But itâs up to us to *use* this effect by spending a few minutes in each mat session empowering *movement exploration*.
.
Once the horse is comfortable with the mat, we spend only a minute or less on it *before moving off!* We use a concept from Dr. Craig Liebenson that he refers to as âfire, wire, sealâ. The âfireâ stage *opens* the window. This can be from a massage, kinesiology tape, any manual therapy OR from certain activities designed to produce an immediate (temporary) change in the bodyâs range of motion, coordination, âfiringâ and activation patterns, etc. But unless we now *WIRE* this new/temporary capability into movement solutions, it will be nothing more than temporary. We donât just want the body to *experience* the new pattern/possibility... we want the body to (eventually) *OWN* it. So we do a few carrot stretches or other core stability challenge on the mat to âfireâ something, then we immediately move off for a minute. Then do it all again (but different). The benefits of mat and any standing core, mobility, stability activities are meaningless if the horse canât *use* the new capability *in movement*. So... we always include a âwiringâ stage to encourage the horse to explore possibilities with the ânewâ patterns.
.
The âsealâ stage is about re-exposing ...

Want strong shoulders? Sure ya do.

Shoulders can do amaaaazing things: pull-ups, pushups, planks, pressing, hugging, holding babies for many hours, and donât even get us started on circus tricks and aerial acrobatics!

But hereâs the deal: your nervous system needs to trust that you have control of a position before it will let you generate power from that position.

A great way to help build this trust is to make smooth circles with your shoulder blades (aka Scapular CARs) in any position you need to express strength from.

Start small, work incrementally towards what you want.

Did you know that we offer Individualized Mobility Programming?

Whether you are local in Oakland, or joining us remotely, we offer specific, progressive programming direct to your mobile phone. Every exercise is outlined via video, and there is not a cookie-cutter to be found.

We see bodies as incredible, adaptive organisms that quite literally store the life and times each of us have had. That collection of the highest highs and shittiest lows make each of us *exactly* who we are--and definitively different from one another.

When people *know* what their particular body needs, then you just need to ... do repetitions. Learn. Improve, strengthen, resilient-ify yourself.

Here is a snapshot of a student who has been putting in the work (check out that 3rd number--86% workout consistency over the past 90 days), and has an absolutely upgraded hip to show for it.

When we are each as different as we are, the tools to progress (less pain, more function), must also be tailored, made-to-fit. But once they are--watch out!

DM us to find out what *your* mobility program looks like ð

Why Kinstretch? An honest answer from Coach @welew_ :

One of the early indicators that Kinstretch was the modality for me was how freely it allowed me to play with the concepts.

Unlike other approaches, with strict requirements and rigid guidelines, Kinstretch simply lays out a few procedures that dance near and around the end-ranges of our motion.

Here, I am exploring my end ranges of hip abduction (aka: how much I can spread my knees apart), and then hip flexion (aka how close I can bring my thighs toward my belly). I'm using the floor, moving slow, and bracing with lots of internal contraction so that I can *accurately* determine if I'm close to my end ranges.

I am *not* copying a shape I saw someone *else* make. I am not "targeting a muscle/group". I'm simply exploring, with control.

The result: improved fluency and heightened capacity at the joints I'm using.

aka a better understanding of my self.
_

Our #kinstretch classes are offered daily, each one serving up a delicious scoop of get-to-know-yourself goodness.

DM is with questions or sign up to try a class using the link in our bio.

#toyourresilience
#allbodieswelcome

#doANYthing

Over the past couple years, we have become more and more aware of the insidiousness of conformity in fitness.

It goes way beyond the cultural norms that are designed to make us all feel inadequate, and strays into the territory of public shaming.

For so many people, the fitness options presented to them involve some sort of general direction to assume a particular shape, with their movements, postures, or even their physical bodies.

And if or when they *can't*, they are told, directly or indirectly (via dismissive, non-adaptive instruction), to go away.

But there is another path, presented by Kinstretch (of which @deweynielsen is the godfather): make exercises that bend and squish and conform to the specific needs of the individual.

As teachers, we let the body in front of us shape the exercises.

Because we believe that no matter what you look like, or how your belly is shaped, or how far you can reach your arm overhead, there should be a way to train that meets you where you are.

#allbodieswelcome
#bodypositivefitness
#kinstretch
#movementismedicine

media.title:
Turns out, we are in the imagination business.

Despite our name, âfitnessâ is just a mere means to an end for us.

The real goal of our work is to allow individuals to be creative.

So how does movement help you do that?

Thereâs a lot of talk about the âmind body connectionâ but (according to the latest #science ) it turns out to be true that JOINTS that move freely, easily, under control, and are *not* in pain, SEND WAY MORE INFORMATION TO OUR BRAINS than unhealthy joints that are starved for movement.

If you make the tools for movement (aka your joints) better, you improve your brainâs understanding of your self. â¦You expand the MAP of your body and all itâs possibilities.

As this map expands and gains detail, your confidence to try new things also expands. Your brain forms new pathways, you imagine new outcomes.

As movement becomes easier, dreams seem a little less impossible, and our imaginations begin to expand.

Make your tools better â> Dream bigger ...or put another wayâ¦
Change your self â> Change the world

It sounds like a lofty claim, we know.

But it is our deeply held belief that given adequate tools for movement, every one of us will be free to live out whatever we may be able to dream up.

Want to know how? Find a practitioner or class near you:
@functionalrangeconditioning

#findyourgold #controlyourself #doANYthing #eatmilesforbrunch @kinstretch

media.title:
Did you know that we offer a FREE Community Class, every Thurs @ 7p?
.
This is not just a ploy to get butts in the door (although if this is the thing to move you, then by all means come join in!). But here's actually why we decided to start offering this free weekly offering...
.
Running this small business is a daily opportunity to live out our values.
.
One of those values is that EVERYONE should have the opportunity to know how their bodies work, in real life, in real time.
.
We've found that by teaching the principles of @functionalrangeconditioning and then offering an environment and framework for these principles to take center-stage, we can reliably help people begin to clarify the physical aspects of really knowing themselves (and sometimes the not-so-physical aspects, too).
.
And while we see the deep value of this work, we also know that in this society, having and making money is not always a great indicator of your actual value to society.
.
In fact, many of our greatest heroes are *not* paid adequately for their heroism.
.
I'm talking to you teachers, organizers, parents (and grandparents), artists, performers, spiritual guides and people in all walks that carry weight for the rest of us, but are never really compensated for it (at least, not with dollars).
.
So on Thursday nights, we honor all of YOU, with a class that will make your joints fundamentally better.
.
It is our way of saying thank you, but also our attempt at *supporting* you, so that you can keep bringing your magic to the world.
.
#Oakland , join us.
.
#controlyourself #findyourgold #gratitude #emotionallabor #unpaidlabor

Did you know that we offer personalized strength training programs you can do ANYWHERE?
.
This is a clip of a pull-up variation we filmed for our clients who are using this programming option.
.
What we are showing here is a really great way to build your pull-up strength if you arenât quite ready to hang from a bar.
.
Coach @hannahhusband sets up at the top by âanti-shruggingâ the shoulders, and bending the knees. The idea is to transfer as much of your body weight (as you feels safe to you) to your upper body, letting the legs help only as much as you need, then slowly lower to a straight arm position (#eccentricpullup)
.
Eccentrics (or the controlled lengthening of a muscle) is a very potent way to build strength and teach your body how to smoothly control a range of motion.
.
Watch out though, they can make you pretty sore!
.
Got a TRX available? Give it a go! Let us know how you feel after.
.
Wanna know more about our personalized strength training programs? DM us and letâs chat.

media.title:
For those of you have been following us for a while, we wanted to clearly articulate the deeper reasoning behind our approach.

Here's our premise: you, and all humans, need functional joints.

Whatever else you want from your body (aka your #movementGoals) hinges on your commitment to maintaining (or reclaiming) the health and capability of your joints.

Further, we believe that every person has the right--and ability--to create this health & capability for themselves, physically.

By learning to control THEMSELVES.

This learning process starts with the basics, not advanced concepts.

The degree to which you can actually control your individual joints (CARs) define the foundation upon which any dynamic, multi-joint skills and patterns can grow.

Even when a student does progress, it is how deeply they understand the fundamentals that ultimately determines their success (however it is *they* define their success). Finally, having quality tools matters.

A carpenter cannot do their work without tools (the sharper the better), nor can a saxophonist, a chef, or a chemist. 
The right tools extend the expertâs intellect, curiousity, experience and aspirations into their chosen medium. 
When the medium is our moving body, the "tools" are our joints.

Instead of sharpening the edge of our blades, we must practice controlling our movement at the edges of our joints (aka, our end ranges). The fundamental right of all human beings to learn about themselves by controlling themselves simplifies our job as your coaches to a simple aim: teach our students to be able to move--with control and without pain--all the joints in their bodies with as many degrees of freedom as possible.

When we set the bar this high, every other goal flows organically, and simply comes down to resources: as in, how much time and energy *you* have to practice the patterns, skills or attributes you want, given the joints that you actually have. [post continued in comments]...

The most unique thing we teach ( @kinstretch ) can be described as end-range strength training.

Meaning, at the very edge of your range of motion, where every human is universally weak, we ask your body to express strength.

Itâs a tough sell for this social-media-flashy-image-and-video-driven world, because it doesnât look like much is happening.

Thatâs because, if you are really working as close as possible to YOUR end range, you can BARELY move the weight of your own limbs.

These clients are doing the body weight equivalent of a HEAVY deadlift.

They are now seasoned students of ours, so they can really feel the work, but to an outside eye, itâs hard to recognize their accomplishment.

So here are some extra gold stars for you, @judyvalgelb & @rachelzak2020 â­ï¸â­ï¸â­ï¸â­ï¸â­ï¸ So why do we bother doing this not-so-impressive-looking stuff?

Because the results speak for themselves.

If you get even 1% stronger in your weakest range, your whole strength game levels up exponentially.

Thanks, #science ! Sound on for coach @hannahhusband âs instruction ð
.
#clientspotlight
#kinstretch
#controlyourself
#doanything
#bodyweightstrengthtraining
#notyoga
#makeshitworknice
#toOURresilience

One of the great joys of the @functionalrangeconditioning  system is how well it works for a variety of bodies. Rather than making the body fit an arbitrary exercise, we make the exercises fit actual human bodies ðºð¼.
*
Here Coach @welew_ is taking his knee through itâs active range of motion at an end range HIP position (external rotation). Working at end-range is hard work (for anyone!) but *improvements* at end-range  are impactful for everyone.
*
One of our goals in opening this new studio was to hold ourselves to a simple standard: always teach classes that WE (the coaches) could drop into and get great benefit from, and thatâs what you see here! This clip is from @kinstretch class last week ð.
*
#controlyourself #practicewhatyoupreach #allbodieswelcome #fitness @hannahhusband

Kinstretch can be hard to describe, but lately we have been getting a lot of âahaâ faces when we explain that it is âend-range strength trainingâ

Breaking THAT down (cuz itâs still a garbled mouthful, letâs be real): - our muscles are the STRONGEST in their mid range - at âend rangeâ aka their LONGEST and SHORTEST positions they are HELLA WEAK - In Kinstretch we take advantage of this universal truth, that all beings are weakest at end range, and we teach you how to safely strength train in that weakest range of motion - itâs UNIVERSALLY HUMBLING to try to generate force in your weakest range of motion - which is why the same class can be equally challenging for a 20-something athlete in their prime, and a 72 year old who is just starting up a training program after years of not working out.

Curious? Come try a class. Link in bio - your first class is on us.

media.title:
Make things as simple as possible, but no simpler. - Albert Einstein
.
Our brains receive information about the movement of our bodies predominantly from our joints (where physical force is translated into nerve signal).
.
By prioritizing the health of our joints, our path to FITNESS become clear:
.
1. CONTROL the range of motion (or movements) that are currently pain free for each and every joint in our bodies.
.
2. Gently but progressively work to EXPAND your options (by actually improving the health of dysfunctional or painful joints.)
.
3. PLAY! Use those healthy joints (and the freedom they provide) to express whatever dreams we have for ourselves.
.
In this video, coach @welew_ is in the PLAY phase, but at a microscopic level.
.
He is Feeling out what the OPTIONS are, one joint at a time, and then letting them start to play collaboratively. [Vid x8 speed]
.
Sound useful?
.
We would love to help you start this journey. Book a FREE coaching call (20m) using the link in our bio.
.
Itâs a big world out there, and we believe every single human should have the freedom to play and explore as they wish!
.
#toOURresilience
#makeshitworknice
#functionalrangeconditioning
#kinstretch
@kinstretch 
@functionalrangeconditioning

How to unf*ck a shoulder, in 3 easy ð steps (ð¥x3)... .
1. Clearly *feel* the shoulder as a sealed, liquid-filled space (capsule) between a few bones that all intersect in the corner of our body (DO CARs daily!) â in this video Iâm feeling what my scapula (and then elbow) can do from an âedgeâ position at my shoulder (GH) capsule. The neighboring joints have a lot to share.
.
2. Engage *real* strength to reach into the edges of this capsule (TRAIN your sh*tty parts!) â here Iâm focusing on a Passive Range Lift-Off: how high can I lift my wrist off my back while ONLY (trying to ð¤) use my shoulder (GH) joint? <âthatâs a question that just looks like an exercise .
3. Link up this snapshot of joint-position (the isometric training from step 2) with your general understanding of âshoulderâ (what it can do, how it can move, but mostly just how it *feels* when you attempt to control it) â Do more CARs, with actual goinâ-for-it effort!
.
So many people short-change the work that their body is so clearly asking for. Donât be that person! Start exploring. This sequence was the result of my own tinkering on my own body. Itâs not an exercise to copy so much as a series of questions to engage with.
.
As always, donât guess about what youâre doing or what you needâyou donât have to. Get assessed! In person! By an appropriate trained professional. #frc @functionalrangeconditioning
.
- Coach Will

We find that a lot of folks have trouble extending the hip (in this case raising up into the bridge) without also extending the spine.
.
Itâs ok for these parts to work together, as long as they also know how to each do their own jobs  s e p a r a t e l y.
.
This is what we often refer to as âhealthy dissociationâ
.
To help isolate hip extension, try placing a block on the crease of the hip. Once you extend, youâll feel the front of the hip become a flat surface that can press into the flat surface of the block.
.
Press down with the hands to ensure to movement, then ramp up your hipâs pressure into the block by driving your feet through the floor.
.
Feel a delightfully deep burn of werk in your glutes & hamstrings and thank us in the comments later! ð ð .
#trythisathome
#glutetraining
#doyouevenhipextensionbro
#kinstretch

We were talking about this yesterday, while driving to Vallejo and back to pick up flooring for the new studio.
â 
ð¸We used to believe that our job as trainers was to keep our clients safe while they lifted weightsð¸
â 
We now understand that our job is to help our clients make their joints better (healthier, more functional, in communication with the nervous system), and then encourage our clients to GO PLAY.
â 
When the PARTS are healthy & functional, the WHOLE can solve complicated movements tasks beautifully (and safely) without any input from an outside eye.
â 
If you have ANY concern about performing a movement, and you find yourself wanting someone to âwatch your formâ â we would ask instead: âwhat is your internal feedback loop? How are you self-assessing?â
â 
Happy to help anyone who feels ready to develop healthy joints, a great brain/body connection, and trust in their own feedback loop.
â 
We open our new spot October 1st, 2019. DM us if you want pre-sale info on the new memberships.

âKinetic Stretchâ Push Up
â 
Try this to make sure you OWN your full range of motion in the push-up.
â 
1. Pretend gravity doesnât exist
2. PULL your chest to the bar (or ground or whatever your hands are on)
3. PUSH your body away from the bar/ground/etc
4. Each millimeter of movement is ACTIVE! You should be either pulling or pushing No free rides, smooth cadence.
5. Breathe! You should be able to breathe and move at the same time ð
â 
If you find that you canât be smooth and active, consider increasing the amount of elevation under your hands (i.e. removing external load)

S P R I N G  is  C O M I N G
â 
Today was the first day itâs been warm enough to do my CARs outside in the morning
â 
coach @hannahhusband Stealing the mike for a moment to say: go play outside!! Quick, while itâs not raining!!
â 
Kick off your shoes and reacquaint yourself with your bare, human feet. See if you can:
â 
1. Lift only your big toes
2. Press your big toes down, and lift all of your small toes
3. Lift all of your toes, and tap only your big toes down
4. Keep your big toes lifted, fan out all of your small toes and do your best to piano key the toes down one at a time, from the pinky toe inward.
â 
Independent control of your toes is directly related to intrinsic foot strength and mobility.
â 
As upright walking creatures, healthy feet are the beginning of a strong and mobile body. Literally from the ground up!
â 
Treat your feet to a little workout today and see how you feel!
â 

Find gold in the little things.
â 
By focusing on the details, in movement and in life, you have the opportunity to make necessary course corrections as you go. But that level of awareness takes practice and patience. It needs to become a habit.
â 
Tomorrowâs newsletter from Coach @welew_ gets to the very heart of habit engineering. Hereâs an excerpt... (link in bio to sign-up ð)
â 
âWhat if instead of being so sure how our habit might change us, we were purposefully unsure. What if we suspended our ability to predict the future (ours or anyone elseâs), and learned how to see ourselves as suspended in the present?
â 
What if a habit was our way of creating context in our lives, and not just a means to an end? What if a habit merely âset the tableâ, so that we might dine on all the delightful, beautiful loveliness in our world?â

Itâs a shifting target.

Learning & change happen outside the comfort zone, says every self-help book and inspirational poster ever.

And theyâre right.

But your comfort zone expands.
â 
What felt challenging a month ago might be too comfortable today. And on the other hand, what seems like the logical next step âI lifted 100lbs last week, 120 this week, so next week I should be able to lift 140lbs!â might not be.
â 
Progress isnât linear.
â 
This is why itâs so important to tune in. Get curious. 
Trust your internal experience. â 
And above all, be honest with yourself. â 
Are you staying too comfy/cozy?
Are you strung out on struggle? 
Neither one is your optimal learning zone. â 

If our last post about hip extension tickled your fancy, hereâs  another great option to try.

#befriendyourbody 
#Repost @welew_ ã»ã»ã»
âTrain hip extension,â the referring physical therapist will tell me regarding a new student.
-â¢-
That person might be having trouble with âtightnessâ at the front of their hip ... or they might be a runner who, without adequate back-swing in their hip, defaults into/compensates with unrelenting lumbar hyperexension (not a problem unto itself, but becomes when there ainât any alternatives) ... or they might just be another someone whoâs struggling in a sitting-obsessed world (not our natural habitat ð ðââï¸ ð§ââï¸ ð¤¾ð»ââï¸).
-â¢-
So hereâs one way to Extend a Hip: isometric strength-training at the very end range. Just like @taylorstarch pointed out recently, most âhip extensionâ training that we think of first (deadlifting, KB swings, hip bridges, etc), terminate motion *early*, before the femur can finish its rotation about the hip socket. Now, staying in the middle of your range makes sense when working with heavy external loads (our CNS needs a buffer in such chaotic situations, to stay safe). But ignoring your corners completely?? Risky, to say the least. #dangerwillrobinson
-â¢-
After stretching open my hip (#relax) by propping my knee on a block, I start contracting the long tissue (knee going DOWN into block; PAILs contraction). Then I contract the other side of the joint (lift knee off block; RAILs contraction), with a lil weight there to seal the cramp-like-hell deal. #ifyouknowyouknow -â¢-
ð¹ x4 speed #gobyfeel #findyourgold @thefitnessalchemists @functionalrangeconditioning

Why is MOVING for JOY so valuable?

Well, we live in a world dominated by Diet Culture.

In case this is a new term, we love this definiton from @chr1styharrison :

"Diet culture* is the system of beliefs that:

- Worships thinness and equates it with health and moral virtue;
- Promotes weight loss as a means of attaining higher status;
- Demonizes certain ways of eating while elevating others;
- Oppresses people who don't match up with its supposed picture of âhealth,â

We would add:

Diet Culture pressures us to participate in certain types of exercise that will (supposedly) result in shrinking our bodies, even when we are getting clear signals from our body that those activities are hurting us.

Over time, this can create dread & avoidance of movement, and a pattern of ignoring our bodyâs signals.

While we in NO WAY want to imply that movement/exercise/working out is a requirement or a moral imperative

...(itâs absolutely not)...

we do want to encourage folks to partake of the incredible ways that a regular movement practice can enrich their  lives

Movement:Â 
- improves joint health
- strengthens muscle and connective tissues
- uplifts and supports mental health
- increases cardiovascular health

(All of these magical things have nothing to do with body size, or the amount of fat on your body)

So how do you give Diet Culture the finger and start reclaiming all the magic that movement has to offer?Â 

One key is choosing to move for pure joy.

Or simply: move your body in a way that feels good both during and afterwards.

For this week's #TryThisTuesday we invite you to make a list of all the ways you move your body that are enjoyable.

What are some new movement outlets that you might like to try?

Why is it that when things are going well, I'm like "It's a mysterious miracle!" and I look no further into WHY things are going well...?â 
â 
And when things go BADLY I become a forensic detective looking for ALLLLL the things I did wrong that lead to this outcome...?â 
â 
I noticed this pattern over the last month, and as often is the case, the same pattern became appearant to me with many of our clients as well.â 
â 
Noticing this pattern, I suddenly had a "duh!" moment:â 
â 
Why don't I get forensic looking for clues as to why things are going WELL?â 
â 
I bet I could find some really useful shit.â 
â 
â 
Whether things are going great, or not-so-great, it's always a combination of actions and happenstance.â 
â 
When things are going well, it's worth putting on our detective hat and sifting through the evidence to find out WHAT WE DID that contributed to this favorable outcome, so that we can â 
a) repeat it and â 
b) +1 itâ 
â 
"+1ing" is a term @welew_ and I came up with while talking about this very phenomenon.â 
â 
The idea here to is see what you are *already doing* to support your goals, and just add a tiny bit to it.â 
â 
Can you relate to this?â 
â 
Do you give yourself credit when things go well?â 
Do you put yourself on trial when things go badly?â 
â 
What supoprtive actions could you +1 this week?â 

One of my favorite parts of our work is when clients articulate what we're trying to do more succinctly then we can, and Lucia is spot on with this one:â 
â 
"I love that your goal is to get people the information and bodily awareness to be self-sufficient."â 
â 
Early on when I (coach @welew_ ) started training, I fell in love with the premise that your workouts could function simply as a way to help you do *your* life, better.â 
â 
I quickly realized that this was *not* the goal for many--most?--trainers.â 
â 
Instead, they were most motivated to help their clients...â 
- achieve goals that appealed to the TRAINER, but had little if anything to do with the actual needs of the clientâ 
- achieve goals that made the client better fit into a cultural narrative about what bodies should look like (aka Diet Culture)â 
â 
As @hannahhusband and have worked and experimented to build a program that truly hones in on providing folks what they really *need* to express the fullest version of themselves, we keep peeling back layers to look for what really flips this switch in folks, what really instigates a re-orientation of their movement energy toward healing and building themselves, and not just performing the arbitrary goals implied by our culture.â 
â 
What we've found is exactly what Lucia articulated above: if our goal is deeply embodied self-sufficiency, then we must start with self-awareness and learning.â 
â 
These are more then hollow words, too. Go ahead, grab a free Kinstretch class (link in our bio) and see what we're talking about!â 
â 
- Coach @welew_â 

How you LOOK doesn't matter. It's all about how you FEEL.

We've said it before, and we'll say it again: training is definitely an inside-out experience.

The change we're working to make--to specific tissues in your body--is obviously *inside*, but the process of enacting that change also involves an inside conversation with yourself: your limitations, your expectations, your energy...you!

Working this way is the best path we know to locate and then work on those edges of possibility that constrain *your* movement.

This "edge-training" takes focus and effort--which can be laughable when you're doing it, because you're working REAL hard to move barely at all... <sigh>

BUT! One of our favorite fun byproducts of this kind of work are all the great, expressive facial expressions - or as we often say, #FacesOfKinstretch 

We see it as a reflection of someone so focused on their edge that they DON'T give a fuck what their face is saying.

And to that we say: "Amen!"

It's true that when you are learning a new thing, you're gonna start doing that thing at a "toddler" level of competency. I've talked about this a lot as it relates to beginning a fitness practice.â 

â 
Just as important though, is to take ownership of parenting that inner toddler, vs letting your toddler run the show and demand parenting from other people. â 
â 
@sonyareneetaylor (one of me & Will's heroes) takes that toddler metaphor to the next level in her post from several weeks back, as it applies to white folks joining in on anti-racism work. If you haven't basked in the brilliance of Sonya's insights, you're in for a treat. Full vid here:â 
https://buff.ly/2ZLyZGIâ 

One more thing--if Sonya's work speaks to you and helps you expand your understanding, please join us and honor that learning by sending her a financial contribution. We can all agree that stress is not good for our health.â 
â 
And as much as I love to see people talking more openly about stress--what it looks like, how to manage it, and how its chronic presence in our lives undermines health and happiness--I realized recently that one of the major sources of stress in many peoples' lives comes from the perceived requirement to change the size and/or shape of their body.â 
â 
For larger-bodied people, this stress manifests as actual prejudice--fatphobia--and comes at them from all angles: friends, family, doctors, and yes, personal trainers.â 
â 
But even for smaller-bodied people, who society sees as thin, there is often an implied sense of needing to change the size or shape of their body, to be smaller, more muscular, less fat. This pressure can be an immense source of stress.â 
â 
Both of these are examples of how Diet Culture maintains it's grip on our society.â 
â 
Diet Culture perpetuates the false narrative that health and body size/appearance are correlated--**THEY ARE NOT** -- and in doing so, entices each of us to spend ever more of our lives on the project of changing our body size in the name of "health" #lifethiefâ 
â 
Which is why when I hear or see coaches advocating for us to all "de-stress" and "get real about the dangers of chronic stress", I wonder if they consider the stress built into our culture that drives us all to see thinner as better and fatter as less-than.â 
â 
While some do (looking at all you wonderful #HAES teachers and trainers ), many do not. And when they don't, they are effectively propping up a world-view that adds toxic stress to the lives of millions, in the name of "health". After all, weight stigma is a real thing, and causes serious harm.â 
â 
If this feels like a new idea for you, I'd encourage you to start following these hashtags: #WeightStigma #HAES (Health At Every Size) as well as these great thinkers @thethicknutritionist @yrfatfriend @chr1styharrison @ragenchastainâ 
â 
- Coach @welew_â 
â 
#allbodieswelcomeâ 
#allbodiesaregoodbodiesâ 
#findyourgoldâ 
#bodyliberationâ 
#befriendyourbody

Hey guess what? We are still wearing masks when we go out in public.â 
â 
As shelter-in-place has stretched on (and on, and on), it's easy for some of the new-normal details (like mask-wearing) to slip into the backdrop.

But it's a slippery slope from doing something on auto-pilot to letting it slip into "not important; not gonna do it" land.â 
â 
And considering our role in the health-continuum (physical and mental health is the basis for anything and everything else we might want to do in life), we wanted to take a moment a make sure we are (still) normalizing the wearing of masks.â 
â 
When you're in public... Wear. A. Mask.â 
â 
It ain't that big of a deal to do it, but it IS a big deal if you don't do it.

So... just do it.â 
â 
And here's a tip from the coaching world: when you DO put that mask on, lean into it, make it your own, and turn it around from being a chore (that you rail against) to a high-point (that you're stoked about) by wearing a beautiful, stylin' mask.â 
â 
We got these beauties from @weardiop an awesome, Black-owned Detroit brand that's rethinking how to use clothing to celebrate and not appropriate culture.

From their website:â 
â 
"DIOP is about inclusion. We design apparel for anyone who believes fitting out is better than fitting in. That means making it accessible to everyone who appreciates our perspective. Which is why we hope that whatever your story may be, when you wear DIOP, you wear that story on your sleeve and learn more about ours, as well as those of the people you meet every day."â 

title:
We'd like to say a big "fuck off" to the tyranny of the Hour Long Workout.

So many folks we talk to have spent days, weeks, months NOT moving their bodies because they felt like they didn't have "enough" time (aka an hour) in the day to dedicate to fitness.

We'd like to let you in on a little secret:

Your body won't judge you for not working out for a full hour, and neither will we.

There are no secret bonus points unlocked when you hit that 60minute mark.

If anything it's likely that workouts have become thought of in hour-long increments because that makes scheduling easy for trainers, gyms, and studios.

On this #FuckItFriday, we invite you to release yourself from the expectation that workouts have to be any certain length in order to "count" or be "worhtwhile" and instead give yourself credit for MOVING in all the ways you can, for any amount of time that you can treat yourself to.

If you're stuck, and needing some inspiration for both longer and shorter ways to move, try these on for size:

- Take a 5 min dance break (video 1)

- Take a 15min break to clean your house or do some other necessary physical labor that supports your wellbeing, and moves your body (video 2)

- lose yourself on a trail for a *few* hours (photo 3 -- that's coach @hannahhusband 's mom hiking in Sedona)

- Sneak in many small mobility inputs throughout the day, 2-10mins a piece (video 4: Coach Hannah currently aims for 3-5 doses of spinal segmentation in different base positions daily)

So next time you feel tempted to "skip it" because you don't have an hour to spend on your body, remember:

Small doses add up over time.

Your body is literally nourished by movement.

Any amount your can give yourself on a regular basis = better than waiting until you have "enough" time.

Our online Kinstretch library is chock full of on-demand classes ranging from 15mins to 45mins, so you can pick the perfect nugget to fit the time you have.

DM us about setting up a membership!

#BodyLiberation #BefriendYourBody #rethinkfitness #HealthAtEverySize #fitnessforall #allbodieswelcome #allbodiesaregoodbodies #bodytrust #jointhealth

For most of my life, the only relationship I had to my own "whiteness" was making self-deprecating jokes about how pale I am.â 
â 
(such is the privilege of being white)â 
â 
The incredible social uprising following the death of #GeorgeFloyd made me want to look deeper, and wider, and further back in history, about this idea of "being white"â 
â 
The podcast #SceneOnRadio Season 2 "Seeing White" has been an incredible beginning to this re-education of our nations history, where this idea of "race" came from, how the concept of "white" came about and WHY.â 
â 
It's helping me re-contextualize what racism IS (not a few bigots shouting at a trump rally, it is woven into the fabric of our nation, our language, our founding documents, our economy, and the ways we describe ourselves.)â 
â 
White friends: if you've been wanting to become a better ally, to get a better scope on all the work that needs un-doing, and to understand how we got to where we are today, I think you'll dig it.â 
â 
#unlearnandrelearn

Did you know?? ... that fitness is a made-up, human invention to make up for the very serious gap that *losing* our hunter-gatherer life-style did to our health?â 
â 
Gotta credit @drandreospina for first making this clear to me, but it also just makes sense.â 
â 
Humans surely didn't evolve *to exercise*, but we DID evolve to move--a lot--every day. And without a real need for that much movement these days--thanks to planes, trains, and the Internet--we *must* make something up.â 
â 
But the MOST important thing is that we just ðstart ð moving ð more. â 
â 
And when we do, we better realize that our joints respond to movement in some very predictable ways (these facts brought to you by #Science):â 
â 
âï¸if the demand of the movement is MORE than the ability of that tissue to absorb and disperse that demand, our tissue goes "ouchie"ð¥ #littlebangtheory @locrao

ð¤if the demand of the movement is LESS than the ability of that tissue to absorb and disperse that demand, our tissue gets better at "handling" that demand. #conditioning #capacityâ 
â 
That's all we're saying over here in the #functionalrrangesystem universe. â 
â 
And once you have enough capacity to do what you want? 

Well, then make up any kind of weird exercise you like ... but make sure you don't have annnny fun ð #whysoseriousâ 
â 
So for today, #fuckitfriday ... Fuck fitness being one thing, all the time, for your whole life.â 
â 
Pick shit up, make a mess, and while you do... *respect* the amount of load your tissues are ready for. â 
â 
âI train my joints to be ready for... (insert demand) ... because I like to...(insert any hobby, sport, or other human movement invention).ââ 
â 
I just like picking up logs at the beach ð¤·ââï¸ ð
- Coach Will (@welew_ )
â 

The absolute *magic* you see above is our client @schreink 's process toward working WITH herself, and finding a solution that helps her get traction with the to-do items she had identified would be a useful part of each day. â 
â 
Karen has had a long and winding road with training--which is the case for basically every person we've ever worked with.

Finding a rhythm with training is almost never a one-and-done solve.â 
â 
Instead, it takes patience and a commitment to "beginning again": trying new things, taking obstacles in stride, and leaving open the possibility that the next day/time could be better.â 
â 
Karen has done all of that and much more, with humor and wisdom to spare.â 
â 
Between body-specific challenges, navigating demanding work realities, and the simple yet profoundly challenging task of compassionately working with herself (*her* motivations, strengths, hang-ups, obstacles, past experiences, etc), required a few key shifts in mind-set that she is generous enough to let us share with you...â 
â 
ð¿ letting go of strict "scheduling in" of tasks: after a month or so of trying to find a slot in the day for each and every intended task, she finally realized that this was NOT working for her

ð¿ adopting a tried-and-true tool from HER world (of education): the Sticker Chart! The whole process was motivation generating, from making the chart, then filling it out, then watching as the colors slowly shifted from not Doing the Things (pink), to doing it partially (yellow), to Doing the Things! (green).

ð¿ turning away from *any* shame-fueled judgement about if the things happened or not, and trying on an attitude of 'just noticing' toward those initial days with a lot of pink squares (or the inevitable future days when stuff falls off your plate). #respecttheprocessâ 
â 
Well done Karen!â 
â 
#clientwinsâ 
#findyourgoldâ 

ð¨ Normalizing Daily Practice RTV ð¨ â 
â 
Such a critical piece of *everyone's* physical process is instigating a regular (daily-ish) conversation with your body.â 
â 
No matter who you are, or what your physical dreams are, carving out a few minutes to explore what your body feels like, how it moves, where it can move, etc etc is *invaluable* to the process.â 
â 
The truth is that all of us already move every day--but most of that is unconscious. By co-opting a few moments of your day toward conscious control of your body you have the opportunity to shift how your body makes all those other, unconscious movement decisions later. â 
â 
We like to use CARs on the daily, but also realize that there are many, many other ways to peel this onion. What do YOU do for your daily movement touch-base? We'd love to hear about what works for you in the comments below ð...â 
â 
Also-- shout out to our buddy @drtrishasmith for one of my favorite shirts (and taglines ð)â 

"The heartbeat of racism is denial...the heartbeat of anti-racism is confession, admission, acknowledgement; it is the willingness to be vulnerable." - Ibrahim X. Kendiâ 
â 
Through the generous and powerful work of scholars like @ibramxk I have slowly become more and more deeply aware of how racism is not an isolated "issue" that a few protests will erase.â 
â 
In fact, racism is a deep current that reflects our innermost fears and insecurities.â 
â 
In our varied efforts to escape that pain, white people have built structures small and large, inside our minds and out in the open, that effectively maintain the racist status quo that got us ... here, today, in an America as racist as ever.â 
â 
I really appreciated this quote from Kendi's conversation with @brenebrown because of how it pulled together so many strands of what is broken in our society right now, and why.â 
â 
Rather than alienating, his language conveys that the seeds of racism are in each of us, and come from that most *human* of all challenges: being vulnerable.â 
â 
The overlap with the anti-shame work that @hannahhusband and I are so passionate about is striking.â 
â 
After hearing this podcast, I immediately purchased Kendi's young adult book for my nephew (I already had his big-boy version) because:â 
â 
a.) learning is the most direct way to change our reality, and youth learning is the most direct way to change the futureâ 
b.) paying black thinkers for their work is the most direct way to reorient the currently racist economic landscapeâ 
â 
In that vein, I hope that each of you--specifically fellow white people ðð¼ --can support the work of a current black thinker, artist, scholar, etc TODAY.â 
â 
Do so as directly as you can, at whatever level you can, and then (in the words of the inimitable @sonyareneetaylor ) "*get out of the way*".â 
- @welew_â 
â 
#blacklivesmatter â 
#antiracism â 
#whitesilenceisviolence

On this Independence Day, we'd like to honor a country and a culture that supports ALL of it's citizens, and offers all of us access to modes of self-preservation.â 
â 
But we can't do that, because America is not there yet.â 
â 
Too many of our fellow Americans continue to be cut-off and actively cut-out of the opportunity to claim complete sovereignty over their bodies, their lives, and their dreams. â 
â 
So we will keep aspiring to live in a country in which Black Lives Matter, and Black Trans Lives Matter. â 
â 
Until then, let's all keep working, listening, and *donating*.â 
â 
Snap4Freedom is a great organization that has gotten our donation, and deserves YOURs, too. (Link to donate in our bio)...â 
â 
From the @Snap4Freedom website: "The SOLUTIONS NOT PUNISHMENT COLLABORATIVE is a black trans and queer led collaborative that builds the power of our people to wage and win campaigns that force systematic divestment from the prison industrial complex and investment in the services that support us. This mission is grounded in our commitment toward ending the mass crisis of passive genocide, incarceration, and criminalization of Black trans women, trans/queer people and the larger Black community." â 

Fuck starting a fitness plan for *any* other reason than #bodyliberation .â 
â 
While this is not a new sentiment by any means--we have come to this understanding through the generous and powerful work of many incredible teachers like @sonyareneetaylor @chr1styharrison @ragenchastain and @mynameisjessamyn -- it is a message that needs to be repeated over and over. â 
â 
It needs to become part of the fabric of what fitness CAN mean for all of us. â 
â 
If fitness is only about conforming and competing, that leaves little to no room for those who feel outside the mainstream to build their own foundation of capability and personal power.â 
â 
All of us are in possession of a miraculous and vast ecosystem (aka a human body) that endows each of us with the possibility of expression, adaptation, and growth. But that's only possible if we are focused on liberating ourselves and each other from the suffocating norms of Diet Culture.â 
â 
Rather than focusing on body size and shape, let's focus on the movements we can make, with our bodies and with our actions. â 
â 
Rather than fixating on how we can out-do each other, let's focus in on what obstacles are truly blocking us as individuals from achieving the kind of physical life we want.â 
â 
If you are interested in finding new pathways through the fitness question, we'd love to have you join our Getting Unstuck program. â 
â 
Itâs a four week online course where we explore how to move beyond the limiting notions of what fitness "should be" and into what fitness CAN do for you. â 
â 
Sign-up link is in our bio ð.â 

When you are used to going to a class for your fitness dose, making the adjustment to training at home can be tough.â 

We wanted to share some insider insights from a client of ours who is now working out at home DAILY, something she never thought she would be able to do on her own.â 

âInitially, during Shelter-in-Place I was worried about training at home. Just how dependent was I on Will and Hannahâs cues and the presence of others to maintain my own determination?â 

At first I did the [video] workouts now and then out of a sense of guilt â I SHOULD work out.â 

However, I noticed that I felt SO much better after a day at the computer when I did my session with The Fitness Alchemists. I felt lighter, stronger in my core and more in control of my movements.â 
â 
Pretty soon I found myself looking forward to my daily 30-40 minutes with my online session â just me, inside myself, following the calm commands of Hannah or Will.â 
â 
That lead me to set up a more and more useful space with a footstool = block, that could hold my props â in my living room. Now I can be ready to work out in about 30 seconds, on my living room rug, with my laptop on the coffee table near by.â 

Thank you to The Fitness Alchemists for giving me options to help maintain mobility during these dormant times!" - J.H. â 

Do you cat/cow? This is probably one of the most well-known stretches for the human spine.

And if you are doing this, or ANYTHING for your spine on a regular basis, we applaud you!

We'd like to offer you a slightly different way to approach the ol' cat/cow stretch for #TryThisTuesday

You see the spine is made up of 26 different segments, or vertebrae.

Each one of those segments needs to move in relation to it's neighbor in order for the whole spine to serve it's essential functions in your body.

Try moving from your cat (round shape) to your cow (arched, or sway-back shape) ONE segment at a time.

Take note of any sections that seem to move as one chunk, or any areas that just feel invisible, or impossible to feel or access.

We will talk more about this next week.

In the mean time, just drop a ð emoji in the comments if you tried this Segmental Cat Cow (and feel free DM us your observations as well!)

#allbodieswelcome
#bodyliberation
#liberateyourspine
#toyourresilience

Athletes and performers of all kinds know: you canât plan on having your BEST on any given day.â 

This applies on the day-to-day level, too.â 

Planning on doing everything perfectly tomorrow is a recipe for failing.â 

Plan for your worst day (week, month, year), not your best.â 
â 

In our book, there's only one good reason to "work out": to open the pathways that allow your IMAGINATION to become physical reality.â 

Sometimes that imagination takes the form of a clear goal, for which you need specific training to accomplish.â 

Other times, that imagination is blocked by aching, painful joints, or a society that doesn't give you space to be who you really are.â 
â 
In both cases, the right KIND of training can make all the difference, and re-open those avenues for imagination.â 
â 
And then there are the times where training can help you feel more sure, and more confident, to try *new things*.â 

To play. To explore. To imagine in real time. â 
â 
That's what you're seeing in the video above.â 

title:
You ever have the feeling that you need to be "more in shape" to start doing fitness-y things?

Like fitness is just for "already fit" people?

It's an easy trap to fall into because most of the marketing out there features lots of movements that seem really effin' hard!

And while those moves can be inspiring, that kind of marketing seems kind of misleading to us, for one simple reason:

the path to doing hard/impressive things mostly involves lots and lots of simple/easy things, done with intention and perseverance.

For eeeevveryone.

There aren't any short-cuts.

Take the One-Arm Pushup for example...it's a tricky move that feels *almost* impossible when you try it the first time.

But like any other challenge, working on this move really just relies on getting over a couple key humps: ðª pain-free and functional shoulders, elbows, and spines
ð« lots and lots of practice, at the Goldilocks level of intensity...not too hard, not too easy, but juuuuust right

Now, if you've been following us at all in the last couple years, you'll see that we focus most of our training on the creation of functional, pain-free joints.

The rest of the time we just ... practice!

But--and this is an important ð--we practice at the right level of intensity. 
In the vid above, that's exactly what we're showing: how to zone in on the right level for YOUR body, even with a magical-seeming movement like a one-arm pushup.

So give it a try! And find out where YOU need to start your One Arm Pushup journey.

If you want to join us for more training like this, that is wholly focused on getting the right inputs for YOUR body, join us on our Facebook page for free FB Live workouts, M/W/F @ 12p PST. We'd love to see you there!

#allbodieswelcome
#toourresilience

"First - what they aren't:â 
If you're looking for the next Bootcamp, SoulCycle, or feel the burn workout.  If you're looking for a great place to get a date.  This is the wrong place.  Save your time and money.  Other folks do that a whole lot better.â 
â 
What they are:â 
Will and Hannah will become deeply insightful, compassionate forces for good in your life. â 
They use movement as a platform to do it.â 
â 
Folks tend to use them in three ways that overlap.â 
1.  If you have been away from activity for a bit too long (maybe forever) and could use a safe on-ramp - they do that.  Things that may seem radical to start will gradually enter your movement vocabulary, but as natural progressions from what you start with.  You will be challenged, but much more encouraged.â 
2.  If you have an old injury that has limited what you do - there is a really good chance the you will discover new ways and create new capabilities.  Will and Hannah are both clear that they are not PTs or MDs, but they are insanely good at assessing and improving movement.  They are insanely good at figuring out how to work with the skills and capabilities that you have right now in order to progress to greater fluidity of movement.  They also get that healing and growing aren't always linear or logical. â 
3.  Finally, if you are working toward a specific goal - especially a movement or athletic goal - you want them on your team.  Period.  They will help you to figure out where your limits are, and help to design a path toward what you want.  They won't be able to change genetics or anatomy for you, but you couldn't have better trail guides for most journeys." -David Bauerâ 
â 
Thank you, Bauer, for your clear insight on who we are and what we do. We couldn't have said it better ourselves (so we won't!)â 
â 
We would love to be on YOUR team (virtually). DM us and let us know what's tripping you up. You don't have to figure it all out on your own.â 

ð¤Basic wrist maintenance! ââ 

Our bodies are incredible, adaptive ecosystems that can learn how to do amazing things, if given the right inputs.

Moving your body is a primal, sacred thing.

Not only is it the way we can continuously maintain the function of our tissues, but it is our primary means of expression.

As babies, it's how bond with our parents; as we grow up, it's how we pursue the folks we find sexy; and as we mature, it's how we leave our mark on the world.

Which is why any restriction on our movement is SO limiting, on so many levels.

That might be an aching shoulder or cranky back, or it might the voice in your head telling you that you need to be fit before you can workout.

It might the doctor who looks past your specific issues and fixates on your body size, or it might be the ubiquitous ads showing you what your body "should" look like or do.

We want you to know that moving your body, in whatever ways agree with you, is your birthright.

It's one of the things that make us human and help us navigate through our lives.

If you're struggling with finding those ways, we'd love to help you get started.

So many reasons... Key among them, though is that right/wrong thinking:
- robs you of agency and makes you dependent on your trainer
- is super limiting & binary (the body is WAY more variable than that)
- ascribes subtle moral value to doing exercise ârightâ vs âwrongâ
- supports the trap of perfectionism (âif I canât do it Right, I wonât do it allâ #perfectistheenemyofgood

To be honest, we used to think that our role as coaches was to teach people the âRightâ way to perform an exercise.

Our thinking has evolved on this topic in major way.

We now see our role as âTrailguideâ - a friendly companion with knowledge of the terrain, who can help you explore in the direction that is most fruitful and meaningful to you.

What kind of adventure do you want to go on with your body?

Do you feel alone in wanting to step away from âright/wrongâ thinking when it comes to fitness and exercise?

media.title:
As often as possible, we give tasks instead of âexercisesâ

Why? Cuz thatâs how the body actually learns movement

A clear objective + lots of external feedback = new strength/skills/options

Hereâs coach @hannahhusband with an example from todayâs Capacity class: -Raise the hips into a bridge
-Press the stick (or broom handle if youâre at home) down with your arms, such that your hips have something to push up agains (oh hi, hamstrings and glutes)
-Bring the feet close together
-March the legs without letting either side of the stick dip!

Itâs not about using your mind to police your body to move with âgood formâ itâs about building a healthy system of joints and tissues that can solve movement puzzles and accomplish tasks.

This requires healthy flow of information throughout the system - so keep doing your CARs peeps!

#tasktraining
#toyourresilience 
#befriendyourbody

However, the idea of CONTROLLING the movement of her spine was a totally foreign concept!

These questions, no matter how varied or splendorific our individual answers, all involve serious engagement with our physical bodies. And specifically, engagement with the parts of our bodies that create *motion*: our joints.â 

The first is Marlie Couto (@marliecouto ), a jaw-dropping-ly expressive professional dancer (ð¸ credit @stexphoto ). The second is Max Judelson (@maxjudelson ), a cyclist (and double-bassist!) who happens to *enjoy* the high-speed, muddy-as-hell, rallycar-racing-on-bikes that is the sport of cyclocross. He's pretty good too ð -- he spent last fall racing around Europe against the world's best.â 

For both of them, wringing out the very last drop of possibility from their bodies is part of the gig. So when they showed up in a @kinstretch class last week together, I had to grab the moment.â 

media.title:
âRepetition is the foundation of all learning.â 
â 
Repetition is the foundation of all learning.â 
â 
Repetition is the foundation of all learning.ââ 
- @drandreospinaâ 
â 
If we're being honest (and we're big fans of that), many, many people struggle with implementing fitness into their lives in a positive, productive way. â 
â 
Either you're lost with what to do, or you can't seem to find the umph to do "it", again and again.â 
â 
And even if you find the "will power" or "motivation" or whatever you call it to train once or twice, the impulse to *return* to the important stuff is not a slam-dunk. It takes guts and perseverance, but it's also the very essence of progress in the physical realm.â 
â 
Dre's message really hit home for us when we first heard it, so much so that we are including it in our Community Agreements (which we'll be rolling out in full later this month).â 
â 
Because from how we see it, repetition unlocks lessons for each of us that might be hiding in plain sight.
â 
"Community Agreement No. 2....We choose curiosity (again & again): Our bodies need many repeated inputs of the same stimulus in order to adapt. When we continuously approach the same tasks with an open and curious mind, new insights inevitably arise." #community
#values
#learning
#toyourresilience

When people feel safe and supported, they become ready to learn about their obstacles.

And once they know how to navigate those obstacles, by building a true sense of what their body feels like and can do, they're ready to push to their edges. 
This is where our training approach really differs.

Many gyms opt to let the competitive drive of their clientele create a striving dynamic.

Other facilities choose to focus on a particular narrative ("we are training you for the zombie apocolaypse!") or gameification (which is really just badly-concealed competition). Other places ignore this "push for the edge" completely, building their identity around something else, like spiritual enlightenment or "correct" movement. 
But we are content working on more fundamental issues: do you have the functional joints you need? are you using them to their full and actual potential?

What we have found after helping many people find function at their joints is that it unlocks a really valuable tool that external motivation doesnât deliver: inner drive.

As in--an impulse to find out what they can *really* do.

Recently, a client summed this up perfectly: when it comes down to it, you must Be Your Own Hero.

Is it time to dawn your cape?

#toyourresilience
#functionalrangeconditioning
#selfcare
#innerdrive
#allbodieswelcome
#oakland

media.title:
A new student said something profound recently: the best part of Functional Range Conditioning is that "you can do it to yourself". She was spot on, and it's one of our favorite parts of the Functional Range System, as well.
â 
While you'll need guidance at first--especially to be assessed accurately--the tools of FRC can and should be applied *by* each of us *to* ourselves.
â 
â To see what's really going on.
â To navigate through the weak corners of our joints, and re-integrate those corners into our usable movement vocabulary.
â And, critically, to guide the continuous healing of our joints and tissues in the direction(s) that *we* want and need.

This is not to say that therapists, medical professionals, coaches, chiropractors, etc. are not an integral part of the rehab/performance paradigm, because they are! They can often intervene in ways that are simply impossible for an individual to "do to themselves" (no matter what the internet might tell you...). At the same time, we all need to feel empowered enough to know who is truly in the driver's seat...ourselves.

Here's a time-lapse of Coach Will applying FRC to himself to guide physical forces into his hips and knees.

#forceisthelanguageofthecells #controlyourself #findyourgold @functionalrangeconditioning @functionalrangesystems @kinstretch #oakland #bayarea #mobility

media.title:
As much as any other part of this studio, our mat represents a central tenant here: we meet you where you are.

Around here, the #stahlwall gets all the eyes (that grain ð¤­), but the ground, where gravity meets resistance, can also offer a great tool.

We can use it to push against, and lean against, moving our joints into *pleasant* end range stretches and loading those stretches.

Then, when we are good and ready, we might lift ourselvesâjust one foot or arm at a timeâwith all our might. #shakeandbake ðºð¼ But what if the hardness of that floor distracts from our ability to focus on our work? What if getting up and down from the ground is not a simple gesture? What if a position doesnât work with your body size, or what if something is actually hurting?

As fitness professionals, if we canât help you find a way to get yourself into effective positions *comfortably* then we have failed our first responsibility: first, do no harm.

But with pillows, bands, straps, balls, sand bags, the Wallâand most especiallyâthe mat at our feet, we can get you there.

Then we get to have fun... ð

#findyourgold #makespace #controlyourself #mobility #healthyateverysize #oakland #bayarea

media.title:
The spaces between... No matter who you are, how you are or what you look like, when you move your body today you will be moving your joints.

In doing so, you will be taking advantage of the particular relationships that your bones have to each other. Because thatâs all a joint is: the space between two (or more) bones.

When it comes to movement, joints are the most fundamental component. When they move well, they disappear to our consciousness, becoming willing servants to our every motor whim. But when they donât, the alarms they sound can dominate your life.

Just as you can learn a lot about someone by how they treat strangersâthe baseline of respect (or disrespect) they have for the space between themselves and anotherâyou can tell volumes about someoneâs well-being by how they manage the spaces between their bones. Asking them to move a single joint with control (CARs) serves as a veritable movement polygraph test (as our friend @getchimpy has so aptly pointed out). Because we believe in truly helping people shake off their obstacles to movement, we focus first and foremost on maximizing their joints. There is magicâopportunity, frontiers, joyâin the spaces between.

When we focus on joint health, every body wins.

#controlyourspaces #controlyourself #spacetomove #findyourgold #functionaljoints

B A L A N C E

Next time you sit or stand up out of bed, take a moment to notice how incredible it is that you can do this.

I ain't kidding: try balancing your pillow upright, or your toothbrush. Even grizzly bears and house cats struggle on two-legs.

Then, as you walk through your day, notice how amazingly versatile this balance is. Don't buy it? Try taking your kitchen table for a walk--it'll surely "stay upright", but it's not going anywhere fast.

Finally, as you pick-up the items of your life, chat with other humans, and think thoughts, notice how effortlessly you *keep* your balance through it all.

Sure, you may stumble or trip now and then, but for the most part your head stays over your feet.

And somehow, you don't automatically keel over the minute your attention leaves your upright-ness.

This is a magic trick that we perform daily.

Next time you hear that inner voice trying to convince you that you are not enough--not strong or fast enough, not fluid or expressive enough--remember your magic.

Remember how difficult sitting upright was when you were 6mos old, how incredible running felt when you were 4, and how inspiring a great dance partner can be.

Remember that we all have the capacity for magic, right here, right now.

#toYourResilience
#everydaymagic
#allbodieswelcome

"I've never felt that part of my back before" As she said this, tears welled up in our client's eyes.

There are parts of our bodies that we divorce and lose touch with.
