ð£ Hey personal trainers... ð£â 
â 
'Tis the season of working with new clients, on new resolutions. And with all that excitement there is a temptation to lean into the shady practice of giving off-the-cuff nutritional guidance.â 
â 
"What's so shady about a lil food- or diet-related comment here or there (let alone a full-blown 'nutrition plan')?"

...you may ask.

I'll tell you.â 
â 
Disordered eating.â 
â 
It is FAR more prevalent than most of us think, and is definitely NOT something you can detect with your eyes.

In fact, part of the *graduate-level* training that nutrtitionists and dieticians go through is how to screen clients for disordered eating and how to respond to that behavior.â 
â 
Personal trainers, on the other hand, do not.

In fact, they're not *supposed* to talk about food at all, according to their certifying agency.â 
â 
So every time you give nutritional 'guidance'--assuming that your own experience with food applies to your client AND is *not* just reflecting your own dysfunctional relationship with food/diet--you are wading into deep psychological water that can have profound impacts on your clients' health. For years. 

(ð and if that doesn't click for you, please go Google/PubMed-search 'weight stigma').â 
â 
You just don't know unless you have bothered to find out.

 (ie: you have screened each and every client for disordered eating behavior)
â 
As a movement professional, there are incredibly impactful ways to help your clients WITHOUT resorting to the same ol' diet culture traps of stigmatizing weight, body-fat, food, pleasure, etc, etc.â 
â 
If *you're* ready to get off the diet-culture hamster wheel this year, we've got you.â 
â 
Join us for our 4-week starter program called 'Getting Unstuck', and build movement habits that support The Real You while fitting into your Real Life.â 

We get it. Your thinky brain wants a new shiny toy to chew on and chase after.â 
â 
But your body needs lots of chances to do the SAME TIME THING in order to adapt and unlock the capacities you want it to have.â 
â 
We did not make this rule.â 
â 
We wish we could change this rule to suit your mind's desire for NEW SHINY FUNTIMES, but alas, #science strikes again.â 
â 
So what CAN we do?â 
â 
We would invite you to re-orient your thinking about training the body.â 
â 
Let's all kiss that old Diet Culture trope of "you've gotta switch it up! Keep the body confused!!" goodbai.â 
â 
That hullabaloo is based on the idea that we are trying to "trick" our bodies into "giving up stubborn fat" or some such anti-fat non-sense.â 
â 
Instead, let us embrace the reality that training/moving/working out is an invitation to our cells to adapt in ways that will be beneficial to us.â 
â 
Especially if our desire is to do NEW things with our bodies (new skills, new feats of strength, new non-painful movement pathways) we need to keep the moves the saaaaaaaaame for a whiiiiiiiiiile and let our brilliant bodies get better at solving that particular puzzle.â 
â 
Ask yourself:â 
How is my desire for novelty serving me? â 
And, what is it allowing me to avoid noticing?â 
â 
Feel free to share your answers in the comments, or keep 'em in your own private journal. #YouDoYouâ 
â 

"You're such a talented mover! That just comes naturally to you, doesn't it?"

Actually? No.

Believe it or not, I was that kid in the back of the dance class who COULD NOT KEEP UP to save my sweet 14 year old life.

I was a newly minted theatre nerd, and desperately wanted to be better at Jazz Dance so I could get cast in the school musical.

But holy moly did I have two left feet and zero memory for choreography.

At this point, everyone reading this post who knows me *now* is going, "Wait, WHAT??"

It's true.

Coordination, rhythm, and physical skill acquisition are all things that I gathered as an adult.

Last month I learned to chop wood for the first time.

My buddy (and teacher) @pariswallace was convinced I was picking it up so fast because I am a "naturally gifted" mover.

I was like, "nah, bruh. I have smart joints, because I do @Kinstretch "

He still doesn't believe me :P but it really is true.

I was a gawky kid with very little body awareness, and now I'm a fluid mover who trusts my body to figure out new movement puzzles.

This is the beauty of doing joint-specific training that focuses on improving
brain-body connection
body control (aka strength)
joint health

Wanna feel what I'm talking about? 

You don't have to be fit, or coordinated, or athletic to do this stuff.

It all starts with simple joint rotations (CARs = Controlled Articular Rotations). We're leading a group through a 10 day program to build up this daily practice. 

It's free. 

It's gonna be fun.

We would love to have you in our circle. (Get it? Circle?? OK I'm done.)

Link in bio for deeeeeets.

Let's go!
- Coach @hannahhusband

I used to think my perfectionism was a *good* thing.â 
â 
I saw it as a helpful drive for constant improvement, a container to hold me in integrity, a standard that would bring forth my best self. â 
â 
The *only* downside I could see was that it would sometimes freeze me in my tracks and keep me from "shipping" my creations for fear that they were not yet Perfect.â 
â 
Turns out, Perfectionism is as detrimental as any other ism.â 
â 
It is based on the idea that there is a perfect IDEAL.â 
â 
Meaning, there is some sort of universal standard.â 
â 
From there it's a slippery sloap to believing that certain types of people are "better" than other types of people.â 
â 
I am clear that I am not here for that.â 
â 
I am clear that I am in fact here to disrupt this false invitation of perfection, and to instead invite each of us to sparkle (or smoulder) in our own particular brilliance.â 
â 
One of my personal practices in devotion to radical inclusivity and liberation for all bodies is this:â 
â 
...Notice where I demand perfection from others.â 
â 
...Notice where I am intolerant of imperfection in myself.â 
â 
...Douse those places instead with love & deep curiosity.â 
â 
To our collective resilience,â 
@hannahhusbandâ 
â 
PS This noticing practice was inspired by @nishamoodley and her brilliant working agreements for the Devoted groupâ 
â 

One of the hardest things for me to learn is how to navigate the difference between internal resistance, and a clear NO.â 
â 
This applies (all the time) in training bodies--my own and others--especially when we're working at the edges of our abilities. And if we get it wrong, and push past that point of NO, we have nothing to show for it but a bruised ego (and maybe an injury to boot).â 
â 
But more broadly, discerning healthy resistance from a real boundary ("No!") applies to any and all of those exciting, challenging things that each of us set out to do.â 
â 
Because no matter the realm there *will* be moments of resistance, when the going gets tough, when we don't know the way, and we find ourselves stuck.â 
â 
How do we decide whether to stop, or to keep pushing?â 
â 
Recently, I have discovered a simple but powerful tool: pausing.â 
â 
As in, taking a moment right before I begin an activity to clarify WHY I am doing this thing.â 
â 
What's my intention? How or what is the target of my efforts? And--crucially--how does this fit into my Big Why?â 
â 
That's what you see happening in the picture above, actually.â 
â 
Wound up into a 9090 passive stretch for my hip capsule, I have a mini-chance to re-connect with what a better hip might mean *for me*.â 
â 
That way, instead of relying on mercurial "motivation" to get me through, or (my go-to) just brutishly pushing past the resistance, I am continuously leaving the door open to the possibility that this thing I am about to do DOESN'T connect with my Big Why, and therefore deserves none of my energy.â 
â 
I call this the "Fuck It" option, and invite you to try it out next time you realize something you're doing is not serving you.â 
â 
Happy #FuckItFriday y'all!â 
â 
- Coach @welew_â 

Most people kind of nod along with the idea of "no pain, no gain", particularly when it comes to fitness.â 
â 
But the evidence has been piling up for decades now: pain (of the physical or mental variety) makes you and your nervous want *less* of that thing causing your pain, not more.â 
â 
And since there's no such thing as making a true 'gain' in fitness from a single workout, the REAL key to long-term training success comes down to smoothing your path, crafting a durable practice that is enjoyable and enriching, and making darn sure that your nervous system wants MORE, not less.â 
â 
This can be true at any level of intensity, too.â 
â 
Finding the right balance of challenge, novelty, and meaning in your training, no matter your background, experience or fitness-level, is the whole game.â 
â 
So this #FuckItFriday we invite you tell those "punishing" workouts to fuck off, so you can get down to moving in a way that feels great.â 
â 
What kind of movement clicks for you, and *doesn't* feel like punishment?â 
â 
Share your answer in the commentsð!â 

If anything, during this age of *so* many people sharing *so much* content, wisdom seems to pop out of the noise even more clearly.â 
â 
Which is exactly how this quote feels each and every time I hear @sonyareneetaylor mention it: wise.â 
â 
It feels that way because it so clearly captures the not-so-comfortable sensation--as a White American cis-man--of realizing my own privilege within our heavily hierarchical society.â 
â 
I can viscerally sense the ways in which, deep down, I may not *want* to accept the lived reality of so many of my fellow humans--daily doses of racism, sexism, gender-ism, able-ism, size-ism and xenophobia--because of what it says about me (and people who look like me).â 
â 
How it uncovers what I don't WANT to see about myself.â 
â 
And that realization is only a macro-version of a dynamic that permeates our lives; the micro-version shows up in all the ways I have ignored nagging aches and pains in my body, or dismissed negatively charged interactions with the people I love, or, or...â 
â 
And just as I am thankful for the gradual expansion in my understanding around the oppressive structures that under-gird our society (from the likes of Sonya, and many others), I am also deeply, if begrudgingly, grateful for other instances of painful realization:â 
â 
ðï¸ realizing that my right hip wasn't going to just stop hurting on its ownâ 
ðï¸ realizing that this business wasn't going to become what I envisioned without getting clear on *exactly* why I do itâ 
ðï¸ realizing that being honest is not the same as being niceâ 
â 
What Sonya is pointing at is a phenomenon that has been studied and discussed since (at least) the '60s: Cognitive Dissonance.â 
â 
And all that research has shown that it a.) EXISTS, and b.) is almost impossible to notice in action, from the first-person perspective; it is a truly SUBconscious reflex that our mind engages when we're faced with identity-threatening information.â 
â 
So the next time you have a chance for some Deep Thinking, when you're feeling safe and grounded, give some time to this question...â 
â 
What am I resistant â or unwilling â to look at in my life? And why?â 
â 
- Coach @welew_â 

Kindness has gotten kind of a bad rap recently, somehow.â 
â 
For us, in a profession distinctly focused on *caring* for folx, this can be hard to understand.â 
â 
If we weren't kind, first and foremost, we would immediately undermine our ability to establish trust with a client, which is critical to coaching them effectively.â 
â 
But in the current environment, in which other values (like: hard work, reach/influence, success, focus, etc) get centered more and more, the guiding light of being kind--to ourselves, our spaces, our communities, even our enemies--has gotten obscured.â 
â 
So when I heard Jamil Zaki (Stanford neuroscientist) on Dan Harris' podcast recently discussing the impact that being kind can have, I realized I had to speak up on this platform.â 
â 
He made a few really powerful points:â 
â 
ð¥ When we are kind to another person, it actually makes US feel better, too. This is kind of a "duh"....but also, easy to forget when we're deep in our shit (which--let's be frank--is often the case in 2020)â 
ð¥ Intention matters...the positive effect named above *only* works if your intention is to help alleviate the suffering of the other person; doing a kindness because you "have to" or for some other motivation doesn't have the same impact on our own happiness (and prolly sux for the person on the recieving end, too ð¤·)â 
ð¥ Our perception about the kindness of others in our environment has a *huge* effect on how kind we choose to be ourselves.â 
â 
How does kindness figure into your approach to life?â 
â 

Making a good plan comes down to balance.â 
â 
Hannah and I have learned this the hard way over the last few years.â 
â 
Beyond the exercise programs we write for classes (daily) and individuals (monthly), we have also learned about making plans as business owners. The good, the bad, and the ugly.â 
â 
And the biggest takeaway, from all of it?â 
â 
Prioritize balance. Specifically, the balance between Planning and Responding.â 
â 
No matter the arena, there will be components and variables that you can, and should, map out.â 
â 
But dither away at that planning for too long and, well, now you're #ProcrastiPlanning ...the special kind of hell-trap for us over here in the #RecoveringPerfectionist club ðâ.â 
â 
On the other hand, you can't be spontaneous all the time, 'cause then you're just reacting and stressed AF....â 
â 
So you get your hands dirty.â 
â 
We *finally* recognized that most of the time, the right next step becomes clear WHEN we take an *action*â 
â 
Move and the way will open, right?â 
â 
Which means we aim somewhere in the middle when we make all of those plans...â 
â 
Draw a map,â 
then dive right in.â 
Fail and learn,â 
with as much grace as you canâ 
muster.â 
Then draw another map,â 
â 
- Coach @welew_â 

A few months ago, we posted this video of us practicing letting our bellies relax out in the open.â 
â 
We were really proud of ourselves.â 
â 
We had recently woken up to the idea of #DietCulture and come into a new understanding of just how harmful #Fatphobia really is for fat people.â 
â 
The response to this post was... wildly varied.â 
â 
One dude just posted the "sick to my stomach" emoji.â 
â 
Most people applauded us for subverting the status quo of trainers showing off rock-hard abs.â 
â 
One of our clients @LindsayTunkl DM'd us privately with some loving, but tough-to-hear feedback:â 
â 
"...in your last post with the soft belly play (really cute btw) I think itâs important to center fatness and the experience for fat folks, instead of centering your thin person experience. I think itâs important to name that you two donât experience the effects of fatphobia directly but everyone is affected by that culture. It just left me as a fat person feeling unseen. If you would want to talk more about this Iâm available as always;) I love you both so much. Thanks for doing the work!"â 
â 
She very kindly offered to help us sort through our confusion and find a better path forward, and we actually opted to pay her for some consulting on the subject of how to be a good thin ally to the #FatLiberation movement. It was a great investment.â 
â 
Then I read an article called âWhat You Call Internalized Fatphobia Might Be Internalized Dominanceâ by @yrfatfriend and everything fell into place.â 
â 
Will and I have always been thin or "straight sized," which means we cannot be oppressed by Fatphobia, or even have internalized fatphobia.â 
â 
We can (and for sure do) have body insecurity that is fueled by diet culture and fatphobia.â 
â 
But that is a key distinction.â 
â 
If you are wrestling with your own body image, if you are wanting to opt out of diet culture, if you are a thin person who would like to be an ally to fat folx, I really encourage you to read the article linked in our bio (it'll be up there through this weekend), and start filling up your IG feed with fat babes focused on this topic.â 
â 
â¥ï¸ @hannahhusbandâ 
â 
#HealthAtEverySizeâ 
#BefriendYourBodyâ 
#allbodiesaregoodbodies

As hard as we humans try, some parts of our reality will never fit into neat, even compartments.â 
â 
Take, for example, our bodies' need for movement...â 
â 
All of our body's systems evolved to be reliant on regular, daily (at least) motion to maintain themselves.â 
â 
So when we try to cram all of those needs into a few, neatly scheduled boxes of time we are destined to miss the mark.â 
â 
The same goes for learning, in that our brains are continuously noticing and integrating new information.â 
â 
That coaching session you scheduled? Your brain *might* be ready to download a ton of new info, but maybe not. And even if it is, it will need regular recall to truly own that info.â 
â 
Luckily, there is another way!â 
â 
First, you can learn or identify some basic ways of moving that are both additive (make you better) AND can fit literally anywhere in your day. Our go-to is Controlled Articular Rotations and 30-second dance breaks, but these movement breaks can take many different forms.â 
â 
Pretty soon, you are getting back to your roots as a warm-blooded creature whose ancestors evolved around incessant, curious *motion*.â 
â 

I found this framework to be hugely insightful. The emotional work of realizing, interrogating and THEN taking action about our own cognitive dissonances is never a task that is 1-and-done...â 
â 
Take it away @leesareneehall !â 
...â 
I marvel at how some approach #UnconsciousBiases ...â£â 
â£â 
After becoming aware that there's a conflict between what they believe and how they behave, there's this unbridled urgency to show that they're one of the good ones.â£â 
â£â 
So, they:â£â 
â£â 
ð¤Put together lists of anti-racist and anti-bias educators to learn fromâ£â 
â£â 
ð¤Show a photo of a stack of anti-racism books they plan to readâ£â 
â£â 
ð¤Take photos with a placard sign at a marchâ£â 
â£â 
ð¤Donate money to anti-oppressive charitiesâ£ and causesâ 
â£â 
The problem is that unless these actions are also paired with inner work and introspection, you may be creating lasting harm.â£â 
â£â 
There's a 3 step process I use to illustrate why going from awareness to action is so dangerous.â£â 
â£â 
It follows the acronym A.I.M. and each letter in A.I.M. stands for a particular part of the quest to explore unconscious biases. â£â 
â£â 
A = Awarenessâ£â 
â£â 
You become cognizant that something is not right. You are a bit shaken by what is revealed. Books, films, and educators can help you make sense of and name what is happening. â£â 
â£â 
I = Interruptâ£â 
â£â 
You use tools to self-interrogate and self-inquire as to why what you believe and how you behave are in deep conflict. This is a process that either encourages you to keep digging into the unknown, or to return to the known world of comfort.â£â 
â£â 
M = Motionâ£â 
â£â 
You design an action plan on which causes, charities, and community groups you will open the door for using your privilege. Not take over, reinvent, or launch your own. Instead, you support those already doing the work of moving us towards a world without bias, oppression, or bigotry.â£â 
â£â 
When jumping from A to M, and skipping over the I, the acronym becomes A.M. which is a manifestation of your ego.â£â 
â£â 
Instead, slow your roll, and back up to the I.â£â 
â£â 
Then after a period of self-interrogation, you're ready to move to M.â£â 
â£â 
What is landing for you with this model?â£â 
â£â 
Please share with attribution.

Nice kicks, bruh ðâ 
â 
PSA: We have all the tools we need for a rich, physical life *built right in*.â 
â 
The next time you catch yourself saying, I'll move when I have the right...â 
â 
...outfitâ 
...shoesâ 
...equipmentâ 
...gym space (yup, went there)â 
â 
...we invite you to pause and remember that human beings are BUILT to move, and did so with ZERO fancy, manufactured doo-dads for hundreds of millions of years.â 
â 
As the saying goes, "You are your ancestor's wildest dreams."â 
â 

If there's one thing we can all count on, it's that *starting* will always be a part of our experience. So we might as well settle in and find a way to enjoy it.â 
â 
Many of us have this notion (expecially with #fitness ) that we will start SO WELL that we will never stop again. (Humans are so silly.)â 
â 
This is just not the Truth. Rather than trying to start "right" -- whatever that means -- we invite you to normalize *just starting*, as you are, with what you have, now.â 
â 
To be clear, I'm not saying starting/starting-over is EASY--because it is not--but rather, just saying that it's *normal.*â 
â 
And you know what else is normal...?â 
â 
Wanting some SUPPORT with that (on-going) part of the process -- like @ckingsolutions is getting from @hannahhusband in the pre-pandemic pic shown above.â 

We're currently in the planning phase for our next round of our Getting Unstuck program, which is our take on how to *start* in a way that side-steps the most common obstacles, slated to begin in January.â 

NEWSFLASH: our bodies are not "on hold" when we "aren't using them."â 
â 
Diet Culture has created a very dangerous false binary:â 
â 
According to the way diet culture assesses our bodies we are either "WORKING OUT" or we are "sedentary"â 
â 
This is problematic for SO many reasons.â 
â 
1. it erases so much of the in-between, and is not how the body experiences life.â 
2. it allows us to believe that our bodies are "on pause" when we aren't "using them" to work outâ 
â 
Under this false premise, we begin to believe that our bodies are cryogenically frozen in between workouts, as though nothing is happening or changing in the every-day of our lives.â 
â 
This is scientifically untrue.â 
â 
Your body is an ecosystem that is ALWAYS responding to the inputs it is receiving from the environment (light, temperature, movement or stillness, food, air quality, stress, emotions, etc)â 
â 
When you haven't been working out for a while, your body has been changing and evolving. It is never static.â 
â 
You may not have been communicating anything intentionally to your body, but it has been receiving and responding to the communication that is always being sent by our day to day actions. â 
â 
If you'd like to get into an intentional conversation with your body, to explore vast adventure-land of nuance that DOES EXIST beteen "working out" and "being sedentary" we would love to join you. â 
â 
To be clear, you will be leading the expedition, but we will be there on your shoulder, guiding and asking helpful questions.â 

Everyone has heard the adage: "Use it or lose it"â 
â 
And while the science makes it clear that no where is this MORE true than in our own biology, I have found it to be a bit...harsh.â 
â 
Yes, it is true that if you don't use your muscles, your ranges of motion, your movement options, your body has no incentive to maintain them.â 
â 
It is metabolically "expensive" to grow and sustain physical tissue and the neural pathways that make use of this tissue.â 
â 
BUT.â 
â 
There is a psycho-emotional cost to how we frame the goals of our lives, as well, and all too often that cost is ignored. We've all seen well-intentioned trainers who will try to *scare* people into taking action for themselves ("If you don't do this workout, you're gonna lose evvvverrything!")â 
â 
And we're not so into that shame-game.â 
â 
We like to frame our training efforts in terms of what they can become, how they make our lives richer, and what hidden pathways they uncover.â 
â 
Rather than losing what you don't use, how about you *grow* the parts of your self that you'd like more of?â 
â 
Instead of feeling motivated by fear of what might happen, what if we were motivated by our excitement for what is possible?â 
â 
Perspective matters.â 
â 
-Coach @Welew_â 

Part of the training we offer to @marliecouto (one of our 'Sponsored Movers') are weekly-ish check-ins where we go over how things are progressing, what she is noticing and learning about her body, and brainstorm the right next steps to help her do *her thing*, even better.â 
â 
In a recent chat talking about some nagging knee sensations, she made an exceptional point: if/when your body feels it is under *threat*--even if that threat doesn't make *rational* sense or feel dangerous--your body WILL move differently.â 
â 
This is such a powerful realization, especially for a professional dancer, but truly for each of us.â 
â 
In her world, where expression is the primary goal, it is all too easy to gloss over those passing moments of body insecurity and just *execute* the movement she's aiming at. Very often, this ability is actually critical to creating continuity in her art-making, but it can also obscure subtle signals from the body.â 
â 
In training, on the other hand, our focus is entirely on looking for, reading, and responding to those very body-signals. That's the only way we can start to unwrap the years of patterning that have gotten us the joints and tissues that we have *today*.â 
â 
As we talked through her insight, she reflected that she wasn't aware of the strategy her body was adopting for the given exercise, even though she didn't feel totally connected with the movement.â 
â 
It took an invitation (permission?) from her coach--me--to try a simplified variation of the move. Only then was she able to see the threat of that more complex exercise for what it was: just a few steps further down the path of progression than her nervous system was ready for.â 
â 
Again, this dynamic of finding the exercise that's the right level of complexity for *you* is a hard truth for everyone of us; but it's particularly striking to witness a world-class mover, who CAN figure out nearly every movement laid before her, start to see the importance of working where *she* is, today.â 
â 
Way to go Marlie!â 
â 
- @welew_â 

It is one of the great joys in my life that I get to train my mother, the source of the quote above.â 
â 
In addition to being my MOM (aka my maker), she is also an astounding observer, a tenacious learner, and one strong mutha'.â 
â 
Her particular strengths partly reflect a specific challenge she has navigated the entirety of my life: Rheumatoid Arthritis (RA).â 
â 
This autoimmune disease (meaning, your own immune system attacks your body, specifically your joints) has done a number on several of her joints, including ankles, knees, elbows, toes, fingers, shoulders and wrists, resulting in a whopper of a pain-journey and very restricted ranges of motion at those joints.â 
â 
In addition to the ways she has learned to manage and mitigate her pain, she has also found @kinstretch to be a highly effective way to *maximize* the capability of her body while still respecting the boundaries on her movement imposed by RA.â 
â 
She would be the first to say that it has been a journey, but I so appreciate the spirit she has brought to her practice of Kinstretch, especially the gem of a framing she offers in the quote above.â 
â 
After taking a recent wrist-focused Kinstretch class, she was describing how it felt to move her 'exotic' wrist joints. Rather than being overwhelmed by the limits there, she grabbed the tools we offered and put them to work *for her* and *her joints*.â 
â 
And, despite my nominal role as 'teacher' in this context, I have found this re-framing to be hugely powerful for me and MY limitations.â 
â 
When I can see my internal, physical boundaries NOT as indications of 'not enough', but just an exotic edge that helps shape my unique-ness, I am much more ready to face those edges, accept them, and then move forward.â 
â 
Love ya momma ðâ 

We are--as a new client aptly described recently--movement and fitness *nerds*â 
â 
We don't just accept the intracicies inherent to working with living, breathing humans, but actually relish them.â 
â 
That drive to embrace complexity is what makes us such big fans of #functionalrangesystems (FRS) and is why we are proud practitioners of  @FunctionalRangeConditioningâ 
â 
Rather than reducing the obstacles that folx face when they move to an easy-to-grasp set of mainstream "rules" ("Everyone should squat!", "Cardio is evil" "Stretching makes you slow" :eye roll:), the FRS system is inclusive to all of the ways that humans might want to move, and therefore inclusive to limitations that might be present as well.â 
â 
This is in stark contrast to the pervasive able-ism that is at the heart of much of mainstream fitness culture: "everyone" is invited, but you're only really part of the tribe if you can *do* certain movements, in a certain way, with a certain degree of competency.â 
â 
That part of our industry makes us deeply sad and frustrated, specifically because of the way it treats folx on the margins, who may struggle to move in those normative ways.â 
â 
Which is again why we are such supporters of an approach (FRS) that invites people, with all of their magnificent uniqueness, in on the good stuff regardless of their background, ability, interests, etc.â 
â 
So on the one hand, we are SO stoked about the "diversity initiative" that FRS recently collaborated on with Men's Health and other partners; more FRS in the public eye is mo' betta' in our eyes.â 
â 
But at the same time, it brings to the fore-front a point that has been simmering for us for a while:â 
â 
Like any tool, FRS can be co-opted for the same tired, exclusionary ends that the fitness industry has been obsessed with since the beginning (e.g. late 19th century).â 
â 
Remember how our society is obsessed with glorifying thinness? And ascribes moral virtue to thin people? And how that belief system causes bodily and emotional damage to people's health, every day?â 
â 
Well, what concerns us is what might happen when an open system like FRS gets grouped in with *very* mainstream attitudes about fitness.â 
â 
[contâd ð ]

We love this quote from ground-breaking trauma researcher/clinician Bessel van der Kolk for sooo many reasons.â 
â 
On top of the empowering message he is relaying about how he helps folx with their healing journey to integrate their traumas, he also got us thinking that comes up quite often in our work: the *arbitrary* boundaries that people tend to put around the way that they "need" to move.â 
â 
As in: "I'm a runner, so I must run no matter what!"â 
â 
orâ 
â 
âI love training with weights, and if I stop I'll lose all my strengthââ 
â 
or even just "I *have* to workout every day." â 
â 
Underlying each of these is a *fear* that without that certain movement or activity, the person will lose something central to who they are.â 
â 
On this #FuckitFriday we invite you to say âFuck you, Fear.ââ 
â 
Because very often, these sorts of beliefs also act as blinders to what the body is *actually* trying to tell us.â 
â 
And sometimes, these beliefs even override panic signals that our body sends when it percieves threat (aka PAIN).â 
â 
Seeing this acted out countless times with clients has helped us realize a key opportunity that genuine, unbiased CURIOUSITY provides:â 
â 
to re-engage with what is *truly* going on with our bodies, and to make a new choice.â 
â 
â 
ðââï¸That runner who gets curious about their ankles and feet might realize what they really need is a few weeks of *not running* to let their tissues heal, which also provides a chance for them to actually improve the function of those structures that help them run.â 
â 
If anything, that person is *more* dedicated to running (long-term) than if they had stuck to their "need" for running. â 
â 
In this way, curiousity allows us to examine & change ourselves without losing sight of who we are & who want to be. â 
â 
And that is some powerful-ass magic. â 
Ahem, alchemy.â 

âWhat equipment do I need?ââ 
â 
This is usually one of the first questions we get when talking to prospective clients about our online training memberships.â 
â 
It's a legit question, especially if you're coming from a background of training in a big gym with lots of equipment.â 
â 
But really, truly, the most valuable piece of equipment any of us have--inside a gym or at home--is the live-wired super-computer between our ears. ð§ â 
â 
Beyond the planning and learning power it provides, which is prodigious, our brain is also responsible for our ability to apply physical effort to an activity. We coaches describe this as 'intent', and it makes alllll the difference.â 
â 
With the right intent, a task like lifting your leg off the ground can feel as hard as a heavy deadlift or bench press.â 
â 
And, amazingly, applying this kind of effort can cause many of the same body-wide benefits that are associated with heavy weight training PLUS a degree of specificty (what tissue is *actually* getting trained) that you can only about with heavy weights.â 
â 
So back to the equipment question...the pic above is what a "Home Gym" looks like when you train with us.â 
â 
Armed with a foundation of self-knowledge, a clear and progressive plan, and supportive coaches to smooth the path, amazing physical changes can (and do!) happen *every day* on living room floors, with nothing but your body for equipment.â 
â 
Fuck it. Take the time to learn how to make use of the incredible gym that is literally at your fingertips and delete the "but I have to go somewhere to workout" excuse forever.â 

"If thereâs a way of understanding our own bodies that can help us betray ourselves less so that we donât have to be mired in the shame of that betrayal, then yeah letâs do that. Thatâs what I think radical self love is ultimately" â 
- @SonyaReneeTaylor on the Unloking Us podcast hosted by @BreneBrownâ 
â 
Sonya weaves together the relationship between *radical self love* (of ourselves, and specifically our bodies) and *social justice* (in the world) in SUCH a powerful way.â 

Though she expresses this through many many channels, for some reason the way it was spoken in this conversation between these two women made it sink in for me in a new and visceral way.â 

I don't have words yet to sum up HOW it made sense to me, so I'm just going to encourage you to listen to the whole episode. (I listened to it twice in 2 days)â 
â 
I can relate it to how Will and I think about training the body, which is this:â 
â 
If we can get into a compassionnate conversation with our bodies, and start to hear everything they are telling us as simply INFORMATION (not good or bad), then we can start to use movement as a medium for that very conversation.â 
â 
We can then use movement to reclaim & integrate areas of our body that may have been in pain, or felt disconnected or unavailable to us.â 
â 
We can then use movement to strengthen and fortify the various parts of our bodies, to unlock possibilities for the whole.â 
â 
If we can do this for OURSELVES, for our bodies, we can change the world. As Sonya says, "Radical Self Love is an inside job" â 
â 
So grateful to be able to listen in on such a powerful conversation.â 
â 
To our individual & collective resliience,â 
@hannahhusbandâ 

title:
CHANGE is one of those blue-chip buzzwords that seemingly everyone can support.

But in the world of PHYSICAL change-making (fitness, yes, but also all the related health and wellness spheres), change can be divided neatly into two types: short-term and long-term.

As in, changes that last and those that don't.

It's such an important distinction because quite often the short-term changes, the ones that *don't last*, leave an obvious indication of change that truly fucks with our perspective.

That's what you're seeing in the first slide above, which shows the impression my watch left on my skin after crossing my arms for a couple minutes (while doing spinal CARs), and then the same arm 3 minutes later when the impression is gone.

But let's face it: it's down-right tough to ignore how a calming massage or a satisfying chiropractic adjustment can leave us with a clear internal sense that something HAS in fact changed.

And while these kind of momentary changes can be beneficial in the short-term, they're quite distinct from the kind of change that most people are ultimately looking for: a back that doesn't hurt any more, legs that don't get tired as quickly, the mobility to get down (and back up) from the floor, etc.

To do that--to make long-term, lasting changes--you need to employ methods that are clear and consistent, and target the *specific* thing that you're trying to change.

Says #science.

And that's what you see happening in the second slide, as I work through yet another spinal CAR, after years of doing them daily.

The challenge comes down to how *obvious* the change feels, because in a weird way, the more consistent you are (and therefore the more clearly you are prompting your body to change) the less *novel* the experience is and therefore the less clearly you can consciously clock the change in the moment.

I'll leave you with a question...How do you perceive changes in/to your body?

We were delighted to get this report back from our long-time client LaurieAnn, who has stuck with us through the transition from in-person training to fully virtual coaching.â 
â 
With this little anecdote, she really nails a major WHY behind the kind of training we do.â 
â 
The *feeling* of physical capability is a personal, intimate thing that truly reflects how each individual is trying to interact with their environment.â 
â 
It is *not* about satisfying any sort of external norms or fads.â 
â 
The appeal of a more mainstream approach to fitness is ever-present; it's usually cheaper, requires less learning, and has the power of crowds behind it.â 
â 
But focusing on making space in your body where YOU need it and building strength where YOU want it means steadily getting better at *being you*.â 
â 
It means entertaining dreams of what you might do with your body that might have been locked away for years or decades. (Before she started training with us, LaurieAnn had just accepted that knee pain would be part of stair-climbing.)â 
â 
It means being happily surprised by your body when you return to old challenges (like the stairs in LaurieAnn's neighborhood).â 

"Effort" is a conscious process, not something imposed upon us.â 
â 
The message that using a high level of effort can push some pretty amazing changes/shifts to our bodies seems to have come across  the meme-waves loud and clear.â 
â 
But what has been left out is that "effort" (and all the benefits that it may provide) does not involve anything more than an intention to work hard and knowledge about how to target specific tissues (which is what #FunctionalRangeSystems is really all about).â 
â 
You don't need heavy weights or complex movements, and you definitely don't need the stress of competition.

In fact, if what you're after is to make positive, substantive changes to your body, those things might just work against you.
â 
What you see above are two examples of Coach @welew_ outputting MAXIMUM EFFORT.â 
â 
In the top picture, he's putting out that effort in order to *lift the weight over his head*; that effort causes some downstream effects to the body tissues executing that task, but those are not the target of his effort (because they are non-specific--there's no way to know what tissue exactly "does" the lift).â 
â 
In the bottom pic, he's putting out that maximum effort in order to *prompt the tissues that lift his arm overhead to adapt and get stronger*

That effort causes his arm to hover off the ground, but that sure isn't the point.

You don't get many likes on IG from just hovering your arm off the ground... ðâ 
â 
Working hard to prove to someone else that you're working hard is NOT the same as working hard to make a change that is meaningful to you.â 
â 
What are the changes that you are trying to make? Are your efforts moving you in that direction?â 
â 

While unpacking HOW racism plays out in our society is a dense, complex proposition, the underlying threat of violence--actual bodily harm--felt by Black Americans is what makes racism an issue that we, as a fitness company, are committed to engaging with, each and every week.â 
â 
When it comes right down to it, the oppression being identified by the Black Lives Matter movement is *all* about the physical, corporeal violence done to Black people over the entire history of America, even today, and how the insistent threat of that violence invades the rest of one's well-being.â 
â 
As two white people, we have a limited sense of what being Black really entails, and how the constant threat of violence manifests as a lived experience. We need to unlearn and relearn the worldview that places people who look like us at the top of the heap.â 
â 
But as two trainers, we have a *very* clear idea of what happens when folx lose their sense of physical safety and sovereignty, for whatever reason.â 
â 
We can see how they lose connection with whole parts of their body, how they cannot truly rest or recover, how they cannot seem to heal over time. That is they cannot do these things *until* they have a foot-hold of bodily SAFETY.â 
â 
This is why racism intersects so clearly with the other -isms and -phobias, and how able-ism sits at the root of all of it.â 
â 
Until someone feels safe to exist *as they are*, they are not really free (Thanks to Ilya Parker for helping us see this connection! @decolonizingfitness ).â 
â 
So whether we're gradually teaching someone how to trust their spine after a decade of back pain, or we're writing a social media post about what should be baseline truth ("Black lives matter") in this, the wealthiest country in the world, we are intent on promoting the simple power of feeling safe inside your body.â 
â 
#antiracismâ 
#InDefenseOfBlackLivesâ 
#UnlearnAndRelearnâ 
#amplifymelanatedvoicesâ 
#socialjusticeâ 
#racialjustice

This truism from famed scholar KimberlÃ© Crenshaw made it's way through the meme-waves and hit me like a tsunami.â 
â 
I couldn't even decipher what felt so powerful for me at first, but there was something in the clarity of her juxtaposition that tapped a root for me.â 
â 
On the one hand, stark inequality--treating the same things differently--is poison to the part of us that wants the best for our neighbors, our communities, our countrymen, our fellow earthlings.â 
â 
But fighting for the smoothing-over of differences, as noble as our intentions may be, actually results in an erasure of the experience of those on the short end of the inequality equation.â 
â 
When we fight to treat everyone the same, to see everyone's experience as essentially the same, to "not see color", we invalidate the lived experience of anyone who is *not* represented by the dominant forces in culture at large.â 
â 
That means that the result of our attempts to bring every member of society "to the table" actually results in simply denying the existence of those people, which is hardly an invitation to share in the bounty of that communal table.â 
â 
But this quote also illuminates a further challenge to each of us, no matter our place on the privilege--marginalized spectrum: the truth at the center of complex issues is often (always?) paradoxical, tricky, nuanced, and resistant to simplification.â 
â 
Since our brains automatically try to categorize our experiences, to look for patterns and clear boundaries, we are not just fighting learned biases when we stare down ideas about race and power, but also our own brain chemistry.â 
â 
This realization makes me question all of the strict categories I've built to house these complex issues in my mind...â 
â 
How do I simplify my world to make what I'm seeing or learning "go down easier"?â 
â 
What corners of nuance do I round to make the issue more palatable to me? â 
â 
What justifications have I formulated to navigate the fact that inequality *exists*, and that I benefit from it every day?â 
â 
#antiracismâ 
#InDefenseOfBlackLivesâ 
#UnlearnAndRelearnâ 
#amplifymelanatedvoicesâ 
#socialjusticeâ 
#racialjustice

High Intensity workouts have become wildly popular over the last 5 years.â 
â 
On the one hand, it makes total sense. They give you a rush (feeling of accomplishemnt, "endorphins," etc) and they demand your focus, providing a deeply needed mental-vacation from the stresses of our lives.â 
â 
However, they are being marketed as the be-all-end-all physical health solution for folks who don't have a lot of time to spend working out.â 
â 
This really worries me.â 
â 
Folks are being told that they can trade time spent for intensity, and get the same (or even better) results.â 
â 
This is simply, and scientifically, untrue.â 
â 
Here's one way I have found to make sense of this: high intensity workouts are essentially a WITHDRAWAL from our tissue-health bank account ð°.â 
â 
They don't build up our savings.â 
â 
That's because...the higher intensity and more complex the physical task is, the more likely your body is to rely on it's most tried and trusted way of solving movement tasks.â 
â 
In other words, when the going gets tough, you'll use what you have easy access to. You'll *spend* your resiliency.â 
â 
If you want to increase what you have access to, to make DEPOSITS in your tissue-health bank account, you need to take the time to cajole and persuade those new tissues to wake up and get on board. (That's what you see happening in the video of Coach @hannahhusband above).
â 
@Kinstretch is one scientifically proven way to do just that. High intensity workouts are not.â 
â 
Choose the tool you need for the physical changes that are important to YOU.â 
â 

Thank the universe for @sonyareneetaylor ... seriously.â 
â 
I've done quite a bit of reading about the body, and yet Sonya's book has cut me right open. From her book, The Body Is Not an Apology....â 
â 
"What if we all understood the inherent vastness of our humanity and therefore occupied the world without apology? What if we all became committed to the idea that no one should have to apologize for being a human in a body? What if we made room for every body so that no one ever had to stand on someone else's foot? How might we change our lives? How might we change the world?"â 
â 
With her wit, wisdom, research and honesty, Sonya has helped me re-examine everything I've learned through a lens of the *kind of world I'd like to live in*.â 
â 
That world is different in some key ways, not least of which is that each of us have enough  S P A C E  to be and live the way we need to.â 
â 
This notion of societal, cultural SPACE dovetails so beautifully with the way that @hannahhusband and I think about the inner spaces of our bodies--our joints.â 
â 
These humble gaps that exist between our bones, and allow for movement to occur, largely determine how able we are to access and effect the world.â 
â 
Of course, this is only a possibility IF we also have adequate space in the other, outer spheres of our lives, free from racism, ableism, healthism, sexism, fatphobia, homophobia, transphobia, xenophobia, etc.â 
â 
Fundamentally, we think that if EVERYone is given adequate SPACE, inside and out, to express their own kind of #GoodTrouble we might just find ourselves in the radical, unapologetically loving world that Sonya describes. â 
â 
Thank you Sonya for inspiring me so deeply, and framing OUR work in a new and powerful way.â 

title:
What should I do now?

Whatever your body-obstacle may be, we'll answer your question with this question:

how do these run-down parts of your body *know* that you'd like them to heal?

The muscle, bone, and connective tissue that make up our physical selves only communicate using one language: physical forces.

Just like you're reading these words, your tissues "read" the forces they experience and respond in kind.

In our view, training MUST be about starting and improving this conversation with ourselves, if only so that the parts of us that are calling for help (ð¨pain!ð¨) actually get an answer (in *their* language) that helps move things forward.

To help with this, we have built an extensive online library of @Kinstretch classes organized by body part.

Which part of yourself do you need to speak to?

We can help you open up that communication channel and really get your point across.

Shoot us a DM for details!

Muscles get all the glamour in #fitnessculture but they definitely aren't calling the shots; your nervous system is.â 
â 
This is one of the key points driven home by @drandreospina and #FunctionalRangeSystems team, and it helps explain many of the "WTF" moments experienced while training your body.â 
â 
Like when...â 
ð§  a joint stretches much further after some contractionâ 
ð§  a heavy weight suddenly feels lighter on the second setâ 
ð§  pain "disappears" when a chiro or manual therapist rubs your shoulderâ 
â 
All of these phenomenon are essentially tricks that take advantage of particularities of our nervous system--not actual long-term changes to your tissue.â 
â 
But the implications of this quote are much deeper (which tends to be the case with most "Dre-isms").â 
â 
He's reflecting on the fact that our bodies seem to have evolved around a single, genetically-derived principle: *explore* the world to find food and mates.â 
â 
That "exploration" hinges on our ability to *feel* and sense the world around us, which is the first half of our nervous systems' job. But our ability to process this incoming information, synthesize it, and generate movements that allow for more sense-seeking is the second half.â 
â 
Whether our muscles (aka "meat") are allowing us reach out to grab some food or powering us up the mountain to look for mates, they are simply doing the bidding of our nervous system.â 
â 
All of this means one thing: when you are training your body, you actually are training your nervous system.â 
â 
Since sensation is the "language" of this very specialized tissue, the more you can FEEL and be aware of, the more fluent you will be.â 
â 

"How do we take care of our most marginalized people and make sure that they aren't being traumatized in the places where they should be receiving care?" -Angelina Moles @fiercefatfemme (Christy Harrison podcast ep 248)â 
â 
One of the ongoing questions for us is how to *actually be allies*, and not just 'perform allyship'.â 
â 
As white people, as smaller-bodied people, and for me--@welew_--as a cisgender man, our intentions to support the marginalized members of our community can so easily become twisted into elaborate displays that feel good but don't really work to change the systems that marginalize people.â 
â 
But instead of letting this frustration--how can I actually help?!--side-line us and convince us that "there's nothing to be done", the key to staying focused has been to build our empathy-muscles.â 
â 
Again and again, how can we re-orient to better understand how it actually *feels* to be black or brown in America?â 
â 
How can we, as professionals in an industry (fitness) hell-bent on invalidating people with larger-bodies, actually *listen* to the experiences of these folx and craft spaces (real, and digital) that support their process?â 
â 
How can I better hold multiple perspectives--my own, and other peoples'--in my head at the same time?â 
â 
Getting serious with my curiousity and leaning into these questions has helped me maintain forward momentum in this long-term but critical, communal struggle, and this strategy has been illuminated for me by other great allies that I respect, like Christy Harrison ( @chr1styharrison )â 
â 
By leading with questions, and not answers, those of us with privelege have a chance to locate and support communal solutions that truly make life better for those on the edges of society.â 
â 
Check out Christy Harrison's podcast "Food Psych" -- it's a real wake-up call for those of us who claim to be in the health & wellness industry!â 

title:
Movement--and all it's delights--is with you wherever you go.

This was never more apparent than over the past couple months when I was not just 'out of my routine' on a 8 week roadtrip, but taking in a whole lot of NEW.

Between new locales, new foods, and new people my brain was awash in novelty, and my body was just trying to keep up.

But thanks to my ever-expanding notion of what 'counts' in terms of movement in my life, I found myself taking advantage of little moments to just let myself MOVE. A #MovementSnack if you will...

Sometimes that felt like swinging my arms--fast and coordinated, or slow and articulated--as I looked and danced my way around random rest areas. Actually, that happened at MOST rest areas, despite the numerous raised eyebrows ð¤£.

And whereas in the past, I would bemoan the random aches and pains of travel even as I felt underlying shame about not finding the space/time/motivation for 'regular workouts', this summer I took a new tack and just ... MOVED, whenever/wherever I felt like it.

Luckily I had @debbbbiee with me to capture a few of these moments, and others I'll be sharing over the next couple weeks.

In each situation, the little 'bite' of movement worked in a sneaky but powerful way, keeping me enlivened during the long drives AND allowing me to dive right in whenever life offered more of a movement MEAL.

By the end of the summer, I felt more embodied, more grounded, than I perhaps *ever* have. And it was NOT the result of a training 'plan' but rather an ongoing, friendly invitation to move. Thanks for the inpiration and FM guidance on this @elkebschroeder ð

How do you invite movement into your life? And can I interest you in a snack??

- Coach @welew_

How do you create a "fitness program" that invites and supports #bodyliberation ?â 
â 
One way we've found is this model, where we blend Consistent Focus with Choice.â 
â 
This client is rehabbing a knee injury, so that joint needs consistent daily attention. (Although we've even built some choice into the daily Knee routine!)â 
â 
Then we've created a "pantry" of movement options too choose from, so that each day she can check in with her body, mood, and shape of the day, and then decide what to pull off the shelf.â 
â 
Oh, and we also encourage our folks to share their non-gym physical adventures with us -- like swimming in a river! Cuz that deserves ð  too.â 
â 
The typical Fitness Program dictates *exactly what to do* each day of the week.â 
â 
We want more autonomy for our people. And we know that life happens. And moods shift. And energy levels vary. And that it's fun to play outside.â 
â 
Our main goal is to give enough scaffolding within the program that you are CONSISTENT about checking in with your body (and with us!), but that there is some freedom of CHOICE for how you actually move each day.â 

As I make my way through broad swaths of America on my epic summer road trip (8 weeks, 19 states, 7000 miles), I find myself seeing @SonyaReneeTaylor 's words above in new and powerful ways.

When I first heard it, I thought of the ways that an understanding--or denial--of the 'other' in our lives might block our best intentions toward a truly just society.

But in the known safety of my house/home-town/regular routines, I am choosing 'familiarity'.

Out on the road, where everything is unfamiliar, this has taken on a much different feel.

As the 'other' now travelling through (complete with California license plates), it has opened my eyes in tiny ways to how this 'other-ing' plays out.

There have been specific moments--like when that WI dive bar that died when we walked in as everyone turned to look at the out-of-towners--but the more profound learning has come from simply 'trying on' what life feels like in places that are not familiar.

I have felt nervous and anxious at times, unsure of my safety, but I have also been happily surprised by gestures of warmth and welcome.

And with all of these experiences, I have wondered how it might have felt if I walked through the world NOT as a white, able-bodied, male-presenting person.

Let me be clear: I'm not doing anything heroic or noble by taking a summer trip to see our country.

But it feels like an important (and needed) dose of the 'unfamiliar' in my life, and energizes me for more.

Because on the other side of that unknown is MOST of the rest of humanity, and justice demands a willingness to go there.

- @welew_

Training your joints to be better at their jobs means your body as a whole is going to be better at whatever you want to do!â 
â 
It's always a sparkly moment when one of our members gets a felt experience of this out in the world.â 
â 
Kinstretch IS functional training, in that it literally makes you more able to perform phyiscal functions.â 
â 
But it doesn't look like what is popularly known as "functional training" in which you do exercises in a gym that mimic the sport or activity that you want to get better at and fitter for.â 
â 
The movements in Kinstretch are joint-specific, which means it's not always obvious to our thinky-brain how they will translate to your sport or activity. But because joints are the foundation of all human movement, your body knows how to make the translation, without you even having to think about it.â 
â 
Which, kinda feels like magic.â 
â 
If you've been trying to get better at a sport or activity and you've hit a wall, let's talk. A lil' joint specific training might be just the thing.â 

One year after the #GeorgeFloyd murder ignited BLM protests across our nation in never-before-seen numbers, we are reflecting on the way that it's so easy to get fired up about something in the short term, but much harder to stay committed to a process long-term.â 
â 
You're likely here because we are body nerds and physical training experts, so roll with us on this metaphor.â 
â 
If you've ever trained your body for an event, like a marathon or triathalon, or a power lifting competition, you know that the strength, stamina, and range of motion your body needed to prepare for those demands took months to come to fruition.â 
â 
Training harder in a shorter period of time doesn't do it.â 
â 
In order to adapt, the body needs time to recover from the training. This is an immutable law of physics.â 
â 
What's needed is to find the cadence that works best for your body, and then dig deep to find the committment to stay with that process over time.â 
â 
Iâm pretty sure that the same is needed from us in the movement for Black Lives to Matter.â 
â 
A flurry of instagram posts in one week while BLM owns the news cycle isn't enough to change the deeply imbedded structures that keep racism alive and well.â 
â 
Each of us must find the cadence that is sustainable for us, so that we can collectively train the strength, stamina, and mental flexibility to bring a new reality into being. â 
â 
If we go hard and then flame out because we didn't take enough rest, that doesn't serve the mission.â 
â 
If we give up altogether because it feels too big, that doesn't serve the mission.â 
â 

@Kinstretch is one of those that gets under your skin, into your thought-stream and changes you from the inside out.

Which is why we loved this recent comment from one of our Kinstretch membersâ¦trust us, we know the feeling!! ð

Once the ideas of @Functional_Range_Conditioning really start to sink in, it changes how you think about everything movement-related, at least in our experience.

And right at the top of the list is how you might support the movers around you, starting with your loved ones.

Nothing smarts more than seeing someone you care about struggling with their back, shoulder, neck, knee, whatever...

But just as Kinstretch and the tools of FRC have helped us through major joint limitations--and the conjoining frustrations that causes--we see how it could help oh-so-many people.

It can sure feel like a radical though, but: you don't *have* to be fighting with your body.

And it all starts with a few CARs ( #ControlledArticularRotations
 ). Even if you don't do them WELL at first, or second, or don't *teach* them well to your spouse ð...

The important part is that you're moving the joint, asking the questions, and imagining a different way to BE in your body.

One of the most illuminating sources for understanding how *humans* learn movement is to study how other animals do it.

This is especially interesting in the realms of animal-training, where focus is directed at eliciting specific movements.

Rather than 'making' the animal do a thing, many trainers now see a way forward that engages the intrinsic mastery living inside each animal to grow their movement capacity.

Which is what I'm learning the (very, very basic) ropes of in the video above with @gioghiz88 and her horse Sombra as my guide.

And while this is a deep and compelling realm unto itself that is mostly beyond my scope of understanding, there are some underlying principles that have truly expanded my coaching of humans (thanks to @pantherflows and my friend @hathaequus who hosted me at their beautiful ranch).

The most important lesson Iâve taken away thus far is this...

...the kind of movement we want (smooth, efficient, un-coerced, positive) happens spontaneously, as a miraculous coming-together of nervous system, body, and environment. It is NOT directed from the top down.

For many horses who have been brushed aside as 'bad movers' or lazy, or even irretrievably 'broken', a shift toward this kind of training can mean the difference between life and death.

And I think the same is true for humans.

Anything else--like highly-cued, over-explained directions (for humans) or negative-reinforcement (for horses)--is AT BEST a shoddy stand-in for that kind of unimpeded movement mastery, and at worst a sick kind of abuse that denies the animal's birthright to MOVE.

And while the mechanism here is tricky and takes an experienced teacher/coach/trainer to really make work, the bottom-line is downright *inspring*: all of us have this intrinsic capacity for solving complex movement problems IF we have the right context.

So this #MotivationMonday I invite you to 'try on' seeing yourself as a graceful, magnificent mover in search of the right context, and nothing less. ð

#allbodiesaregoodbodies
#AffirmingFitness
#InclusiveFitness

It doesn't matter how awesome the workout is... if your nervous system isn't feeling safe, you're gonna be stopped at a red light ð¦.

No matter how much you might *want* a certain movment or position, if your body isn't feeling safe--a bottom baseline--it's really not worth pushing through.

Not for one more set, one more inch of stretch, one more rep.

Instead, you'll need to zoom on how to proceed with a little LESS.

And the way your body let's you know to STOP (and adjust) is as diverse and varied as we humans are, tho fortunately there are some common overlaps that clue us in...
ð¥ pain
ð¥ trouble breathing calmly
ð¥ limbs 'falling asleep'
ð¥ general feelings of anxiety
ð¥ even dizzyness/nausea.

In each case, your body is doing it's best to send physical signals that while it's *possible* to go further, it likely won't go so well.

This gets especially tricky when you actually feel like you NEED a certain position--like the set-up for shoulder external rotation the above #ClassClip is from.

Which is why we are continuously reminding our students that you gotta hunt out *your* range, *your* positions, that allow you to feel safe, solid and ready to *work*.

Going beyond that--disrespecting your Current You--is a short-term play that doesn't serve Future You.

And we say #FuckItFriday to that -ish!! Happy Weekend y'all ð¤

There is a learning curve to understanding what's going on inside yo'self.

No one can do that learning for you.

It's verrrry much like learning a language... at first, you feel like a toddler, struggling to find the words to express what you want and need.

Then, the more fluent you get, the more specific and effective you can be at both *listening* to what your body needs AND *directing* it to get better at whatever YOU want to do.

And the best part? You get to hold onto all that understanding; your efforts compound over time.

One weird part about this language is that it isn't spoken and heard, but is actually in the form of mechanical forces: tension and stretch, sensation and motion.

"Force is the language of our cells," as @drandreospina has been saying for years.

Of course, there is always another option: turn away from knowing how your body communicates, and skip the crucial steps in learning how to speak BODY.

But that almost always leads to a scenario where our body resorts to the equivalent of yelling and screaming, which in BODY-speak shows up as pain and dysfunction.

All too often, this leads to quick-fixes to get out of pain that don't really address the underlying causes.

Pretty soon, the yelling starts again, and round and round we go.

Which is why we so strongly encourage YOU to say #FuckItFriday and leave aside the societal bullshit telling you how or why you *should/shouldn't* move in a certain way, and instead start communicating directly with *your* sweet, incredible body.

It has a lot to share.

Most of the time, limitations at our joints are sneaky, 'hiding' in plain sight.

And while they'll do their best to show up however we're asking them to--running, playing tennis, slaying zombies--it almost always takes a little digging to find out what's really going on in your back, your hip, or (like Anne describes up thereð) your ankle.

Otherwise, the only way you're clued into what your body needs is when you get to that final stage of dysfunction, also known as 'Ouchie!!'

Things go muuuuch smoother when you can get into conversation with your body *before* the alarm bells start ringing (aka ð¨ PAIN ð¨).

Instead, you can start 'digging'.

By which I mean applying the tools of @Functional_Range_Conditioning and @Kinstretch to explore yourself, specifically with CARs, an incredible swiss-army knife tool that helps you assess AND maintain your joints all in one.

Then, armed with more clarity about how that joint is working, you can really get down to business and make the changes that your body needs.

This is why we categorize our library of Kinstretch classes by joint; this way our online Kinstretch members can go right to the material that *their* body is asking for, and get to work upgrading their meat-suit.

- Coach @welew_

M O T I V A T I O Nâ 
â 
is like... 90% of the reason most people hire a trainer, or sign up for a class-based membership.â 
â 
It's something Will and I put a lot of thought into.â 
â 
There's a couple things I want to straight-up normalize: Motivation to move your body F L U C T U A T E S.â 
â 
So if that's you, you're normal. You're not failing. There's nothing wrong with you.â 
â 
I repeat: There is nothing wrong with you, if you don't roll out of bed every single day STOKED to move your body.â 
â 
The kind of motivation that can stoke a lifetime can't be single sided. We humans are too variable, and life is too random.â 
â 
That long-haul motivation needs to be something that has polarity to it, so it can flex with us as things shift.â 
â 
I talked about this last week, and I'm gonna keep saying it, cuz I really think we are on to something here:â 
â 
JOY + TENDINGâ 
â 
Movement practices flourish and motivation simmers in steady supply when these two polarities are present.â 
â 
Have you had a time in your life when you felt like you were bothâ 
â 
...Tending to the parts that need more strength, more resilience, more flexibilityâ 
â 
andâ 
â 
...Joyfully moving your body in ways that felt playful, exploratory, exciting, and/or great for your mental health?â 
â 
It could begin with just 10mins a day of each. Or even 5mins of each.â 
â 
If motivation has been a challenge for you, I've love to hear how this concept is landing for you.â 
â 
In your corner,â 
Coach @HannahHusbandâ 

One of my favorite nerd-tastic words is 'affordance'.â 
â 
According to trusty wikipedia, 'affordances are what the environment offers the individual'.â 
â 
It's such a great way of describing the profound ways that we compliment our environment, being shaped by our surroundings even as *we* shape those very surroundings.â 
â 
An affordance is that window ledge that offers you the perfect lookout perch, that 5-gallon bucket that (flipped over) transforms into a perfect drum, and also that pesky crack in the sidewalk that you subconsciously change stride to accommodate.â 
â 
Great designers think about the way that products 'afford' their users certain possibilities, as do urban planners, architects, and sports scientists.â 
â 
In each realm, the fact that humans use direct awareness of environmental cues to shape their understanding of the world--and their unique possibilities within that world--means that if you can change someone's environment, even subtly, you can definitively change their life.â 
â 
ð¤¯â 
â 
As a fitness coach, focused on how to impact the *internal* environment of bodies, I also see this interaction between a person and their environment at play when they access MOAR movement options (by expanding the usable range of motion of their joints).â 
â 
Suddenly, that too-high-to-reach-shelf is not so high when your shoulder allows your arm bones to go alllllll the way behind your ear.â 
â 
Suddenly that low cupboard where you keep your big stock pot is not a job for hands-and-knees, not when you have a hip that allows you to squat or lunge down to grab it.â 
â 
Suddenly that too-steep-for-my-knees bike ride is not just doable but down right exhilarating (that's what's going on in the pic above--photo cred to the inimitable @true_spokes )â 
â 
Of course, this 'sudden' re-orientation within our environments is not necessarily quick--the work of changing our tissues to accommodate more stable movement is substantial, and takes persistence.â 
â 
But the pay-off can be life-changing.â 
â 
How would your world change if your joints afforded you even 5% more .... (fill in the blank)?â 
â 
- Coach @welew_â 
â 
#ThinkyThursdayâ 
#FitnessByFeelâ 
#BodyLiberationâ 
#BefriendYourBody

title:
Motivation to MOVE is a balancing act between two essential movement nutrients:
JOY + TENDING.

We need to move in ways that bring us in-the-moment JOY. (It's immediately rewarding and life-enriching.)

And, for most of us, there are parts of our bodies that are asking for some specific tending.

...an ankle that complains when we run

...a tender low back that doesn't appreciate the high-octane kitchen dance party we got up to last night

...wrists that aren't ready to support our bodyweight

...a hip that aches after a long day

These parts that need tending can change, and they are going to need:

- specific inputs, to invite the adaptation that we want

- consistent inputs, over enough time

What we have found is that it doesn't work to completely put movement-joy on hold, while we "fix" the part(s) that need tending.

Connecting with activities that you love -- that bring that joyous sparkle -- help us feel motivated to do the tending stuff.

The Tending opens up more options for Joy.

It's a virtuous cycle.

How are you accessing embodied JOY these days? What are you TENDING to in your body?

#mondaymotivation
#bodyliberation
#befriendyourbody
#allbodiesaregoodbodies
#AffirmingFitness
#InclusiveFitness"

Too often, we see our bodies as "just a body", *just* a piece of meat, just a source of frustration, and one that's usually "not enough..." something.â 

This is part of why we love @virgietovar 's work--her writing, her workshops, her *amazing* IG account--so dang much.â 

She said this quote (above) during a presentation we attended a few months back, after guiding the group of us through a body-oriented meditation (over zoom--it was impressive).â 
â 
In that moment, all of my intellectual understanding about training and bodies fell away, and in it's place I was left that particular feeling of witnessing powerful art.â 
â 
Only, instead of gawking at an impressive expert or a famous celebrity, I had simply been experience my own, human body in all it's roughness and smoothness, it's awkwardness and its grace.â 
â 
So rather than assuming that a body could possibly be one thing, that HEALTHY could possibly be the same thing for different people, that beauty could possibly be seen the same by all people, try looking at bodies--our own and each others--as if they were pieces of art.â 
â 
You're in for a treat.â 

So often our clients want to know Which Way Is Right?â 

There is no One Right Answer to that question.â 

Usually, on first glance, people understand that @KINSTRETCH involves ... stretching ð¤£.

And it does--sort of--but I'll get to that.

But first, what about that other part, the 'KIN-'?

It comes from 'kinetic' as in: "relating to the motion of material bodies and the forces and energy associated therewith" (from MerriamWebster) ... so wordy!

I like the Greek verb that it is derived from (kinein: 'to move') better, 'cause it's simple AND gets to the very heart of what we're focused on in Kinstretch: MOVING.

Because in Kinstretch, we are deconstructing the fundamental tools for human movement--from the cellular level all the way up to very largest movements of our joints--and focusing our effort at directly improving those tools.

Rather than imitating certain forms or postures, in Kinstretch we are intent on working directly with our own exprience, our own body, to understand what is NEEDED, and then giving ourselves THAT.

And it's all toward movement....More, better, easier MOVEMENT.

So while there may be moments of relaxed, static 'stretching', as well as moments of isometric ("Go nowhere") training, those are just a couple of the MANY tools of Kinstretch.

And each of those tools are focused on one thing: helping your body move *better*.

The snazzy video above is from our KinFam over at #FunctionalRangeSystems and they nail it with that sign off....

Kinstretch: Do Anything.

What if you were able to believe that already, right now, you are *doing it right*?

What if you were able to be generous with yourself, and see the glass of your experience as half-full?

What if the paths you see for yourself to PROGRESS or GROW were just *options* in front of a YOU that was already doing a great job?

How would that shift your relationship with yourself?

How would that relieve the constant barrage of 'SHOULD's and 'YEAH, BUT'sâ that undercut so many of us?

How would that expand your world-view, and the moves you could make in that expanse?

This kind of thought experiment isn't some kind of believe-it-into-reality ploy, but rather just an idea to play with, and maybe to balance out the chorus of dissent that can dominate our inner worlds.

Objectively speaking, our being is replete with natural miracles, miracles of sensation, of consciousness, of transformation.

Our minds, on the other hand, can sometimes stagnate with an underlying belief that we are NOT doing it right.

But what if, just for a moment, you were able to believe that actually, right now ... you are doing it right?

Here's to finding your gold ð»,
Coach @welew_

Your Body As Oasis
{a poem by @welew_ }

Your body can be that place
where you are safe.

It can be your refuge, your escape, 
the bringer of ecstasy and understanding.

But it can also stand
in your way.

Its sharp edges and blind corners
shredding your visions of

Lofty, strenuous vistas and soft midnights,
the coldest plunge and the deepest satisfaction.

The harbor of your body
protects the deep waters of 
real physicality, of
physical reality.

Your body
sings,
longing for motion
and craving rest.

Its desires seethe, hungrily
exploring sensation, directed
or not.

But it can be all of these things
only if it is yours, 

if you are sovereign
in your own domain, and not subject
to the hateful words or
marketing campaigns
or failed delusions
of whiteness, of thinness, of swole-ness, 
of capital over humanity.

So forge the piers
that will give you access
to the murk within
your harbor.

Looking down, smiling
at your reflection,
gaze further, longer, deeper,
to the very foundation of
your sensation.

Your body can be 
that place
where you are safe.

#FuckItFriday
#RecoveringPerfectionist

title:
We can only begin with the body, being, and schedule that you have ð  right ð  meow ð»

If we start with a goal, and then "work our way backward" what tends to happen is that our "first steps" are much closer to that Future You than to Current You.

Which means they will be pretty lofty and inaccessible steps for Current You to execute.

Like trying to keep pace with a grown-up's stride when all you've got are toddler legs.

It's just unfair.

What if, instead, you began by focusing on Current You?

What if you spent some time each day -- just 10-15mins -- getting to deeply know Current You.

As you explore your current sitch, new things will get noticed.

In the same way that when you explore a forest, you discover different trails, birds, patches of shade.

New options will surface, and you'll have the opportunity to play with them.

To *move* in a new direction.

You'll easily be able to take these new steps, because they are right under foot.

The fitness industry at large is so enamored with #Goals -- especially here on Instagram.

On this #FuckItFriday, we're here to nudge you in a different direction.

If you've done the goals thing a bunch, and it hasn't been what you'd hoped, we'd love to talk to you about what an inside-out approach might feel like for you. Shoot us a DM, or book a free call using the link in our bio.

We're coaching virtually now, so wherever you are, we can be there to take those first under-your-nose steps with you.

On we merrily stumble,
Coach @hannahhusband
