media.title:
There was a time that I thought that there was clearly a *best* way I could train my body.â 
â 
It basically came down to: what exercises/workouts would give me the most 'bang for my buck'? Which movements would "help me" the *fastest*?â 
â 
These are similar to questions we hear from our members (and prospective members) alllll the time. Because #efficiencyâ 
â 
My answer--at that time--came down to picking the hardest/heaviest exercises.â 
â 
So I did a lot of deadlifts and squats, basically, and not much of anything else ð.â 
â 
But I was missing a key aspect of *how* our bodies handle big, weight-y tasks.â 
â 
I didn't realize that lifting more weight was as much about actually being able to utilize my whole body--*all* the meat that attached to *all* my joints--as it was about just asking the same tissue to WORK HARDER.â 
â 
Because while those moves did demand a lot from the tissue my nervous system actually "knew" about, it didn't do anything about helping me access *more* tissue.â 
â 
In fact, by hammering those same patterns over and over, I was teaching my body to do (and use) *what it already knew* and NOT to be able to do new things.â 
â 
And what it already knew was what it felt like to lift weights with painful joints...which I was practicing, over and over.â 
â 
And I know it's not #FuckItFriday yet, but...fuck that ðâ 
â 
These days, I know more, and so I do better (which is all that we can ever ask of ourselves, right?).â 
â 
That's what you see going down above....~50min of training is condensed into an IG minute, showing how I go about training my body, now.â 
â 
I know now that my body doesn't just offer up new tissues because I try real hard, but instead needs *specific* inputs.â 
â 
I know now that my brain doesn't just learn how to control my body because I pour on more intensity, but instead needs patient, focused repetition.â 
â 
And I know now that sometimes my efforts at âefficiencyâ  actually represent the least efficient movement choice.â 
â 
- Coach @welew_â 

We are adamant that by far the most critical step to *actually establishing a habit* is the FIRST one.â 
â 
You cannot find that groove in your schedule or celebrate process wins--both characteristics of a potent, on-going practice--if you haven't gotten really good at *starting*.â 
â 
Which is why we make such a big deal when our members just *start* one of their classes or workouts (as evidenced by that screenshot from our training app up ð).â 
â 
And one way we know that it's so important to lift up and reward (via the all-powerful â) ?

Because we sometimes see resistance to this approach in real time, from our members!â 
â 
They basically make the (very valid) point that what *they* need in terms of coaching and accountability is having someone who will hold them to their intentions of moving their body and improving their mobility.â 
â 
And in their view, simply *starting* a workout is NOT honoring that intention.â 
â 
But after many, many years of helping humans move their bodies, we know that each and every input (movement sesh, workout, etc) must simultaneously respect where that mover is currently AND set them up for more positive movement experiences in the future.â 
â 
On the other hand, only allowing yourself to celebrate when you have 'finished' a thing is short-sighted, because having a body is never a singular event.

You're not 'done' with your body just because you have finished your workout.â 
â 
What's more, this kind of 'completion-ist' view stinks of perfectionism, which itself reeks of white supremacy and partiarchy. Let's #SmashTheHierarchy ya?â 
â 
Instead, by getting a feel for the power of starting, and taking pride in simply stepping over that threshold between thought and action, a person builds a skill that will serve them at every stage of their movement journey.â 
â 
How are you positively reinforcing STARTING in your life?â 
â 
- Coach @welew_â 

We're in the practice of helping folks reclaim body trust.â 
â 
We believe this happens through compassionnate communication with our tissues, our thoughts, our SELVES.â 
â 
Sensation is the language our bodies speak to us.â 
â 
Aches, stiffness, sharp pinches, juicy stretches, zingy tingles.â 
â 
It's alllllllllll information, coming your way.â 
â 
This clip is an "off the record" moment we happened to capture on video during our last filming week.â 
â 
In it, I'm unpacking all the wonderful information I gleaned from a #Kinstretch class we had just filmed, in which I was the model and Will was the teacher.â 
â 
In our @Kinstretch classes, we are always aiming to have a 2-way conversation with our bodies.â 
â 
We speak to the tissues with "force" aka stretegically applied stress or tension, created by stretching and engaging muscle and joint tissues at specific angles.â 
â 
But while we are talking, we are also LISTENING.â 
â 
What sensations are present?â 
Are some of them surprising?â 
Are some of them pleasurable? Some not?â 
How might we speak to this same joint (in this case the ankle) differently next time, based on what we heard this time?â 
â 
Did you take some time to talk to your body today? What did you say? What did you hear?â 
â 
xx,â 
Coach @HannahHusbandâ 

Just in case you need this reminder today: The pursuit of health is *not* a moral obligation.â 

Also, as @RagenChastain so wisely said in a recent workshop we took:â 
â 
" 'health' is an amorphous concept, that is very difficult to define. But we talk about it like it's easy to define."â 
â 
Not only is it difficult to define, there is no ONE definition that fits every single person.â 
â 
Sometimes the "healthiest" thing you can do for yourself is to deeply rest.â 
â 
Sometimes life circumstances are such that "health" is not at the top of your priority list -- and that's ok too.â 

You deserve to choose what is right for you, given your full life picture.â 
â 
So on this #FuckItFriday we invite you to take a deep breath, set down any guilt you may be carrying for not pursuing "health" with every available resource, and let today be good enough, as is.â 

Itâs a common saying in the fitness industry:

âAbs are made in the kitchenâ

What they are really saying is:

âYou canât out-train a âbadâ dietâ

aka  you canât *just* workout and eat whatever you want and expect to get washboard abs.

Hold on - I just threw up in my mouth a lilâ bit. 

Ok Iâm back.

We just wanna remind you that every human being alive has Every ð Single ð Muscle ð from birth.

Thatâs right, we come into this world with everything we will ever need.

We can certainly take actions in our lifetime to increase the size, strength, and visibility of any muscle we choose.

Your midsection, your belly âwhatever you want to call that glorious stretch of humanity between your ribs and your pelvis â comes standard with âabsâ the same way your arms come with âbicepsâ and your mouth comes with a tongue.

You donât have to go out and acquire these marvelous tissues, you already have them.

You also donât have to torture yourself with food restriction until they become âvisibleâ â you can be strong, happy, and healthy at any size.

âVisible absâ are not a required indication of a healthy human. And if anyone says they are, thatâs #fatphobia talking.

Hereâs to loving our strong bellies in all their forms,
Coach @hannahhusband

title:
Early on, I learned that the very best parts of life--the most alive, most creative, most rich--share a critical trait: they end.

Unlike objects that persist even after they are thrown away, those most valuable aspects of our experience are so valuable exactly because they don't last forever.

And so it is with the commercial lease of our studio.

Thanks to Covid, a prolonged visit from the Wicked Witch of Plumbing Mishaps, and the clarity that came with dealing with both, Hannah and I decided (after much hand- and heart-wringing) that the best next step for The Fitness Alchemists was to leave the brick-and-mortar gym-owner life behind.

This leaves us with much more bandwidth to keep exploring the wide world of online movement/mobility coaching.

Working with people in this way, oddly, has been a big bright spot of this last year.

Being able to coach through an internet connection offers a closeness to our members' day-by-day movement life that was completely impossible when we only saw people in-person, and the results for our members have been undeniable.

So while we will miss the way the morning sun warmed our mats, the spectacular backdrop our #StahlWall provided for allll the filming, the community that was kindled inside those walls, and so much more, we look ahead to the shape of things to come.

All of the work and energy that went into crafting our space will still be composting for some time, but we can't wait to see what grows next. ð±

Thank YOU for being on this journey with us, and stay tuned ð¤©.

In the words of the one and only Coach @hannahhusband : 'On we merrily stumble.'

- Coach @welew_

F O C U S I N G  is hard.

Especially now that so many of us are stuck at home: working, home-schooling, parenting, cooking, cleaning, living IN THE SAME SPACE ALL THE TIIIIIIME.

It's been surprising to many of our members how hard it is to carve our space to MOVE in this current reality.

So we wanted to share one strategy that is working well for our peeps.

â¨10 Minute Moveâ¨

1. Pick a strength move you like (one that is "in your wheelhouse")
...one that makes you feel powerful
...doesn't cause pain or threat
...that you actaully look forward to doing!

2. Set a timer for 10 minutes
...use your phone timer, couting down, so you can see how much time is elapsed/remaining
...you can use a fancy timer app, but you don't need one!

3. Every minute, on the minute, do X reps of your strength move
...choose the reps based on what feels totally do-able
...it should leave you at least 30 seconds of rest before the next minute starts (doesn't have to be exact -- fire your inner perfectionist for this one, k?)

4. Get to WERK.
... a good soundtrack can be the perfect back-up dancer (just sayin')

Hit us up with clarifying questions, or share your feedback in the comments.

What's your fave strength move?

Happy to help you come up with a good one to suit your body. Hit us up in the comments or send us a DM.

talk soon,
Coach @hannahhusband

PS I made a 10 Minute Move playlist on our Spotify â link in bio if ya need some good tunes!

Black History *is* American History...what about Black Futures?â 
â 
White American ancestors moved onto what became 'American' land, claimed it unilaterally, and proceeded to kill off the Indigenous people who had lived on that land for thousands of years. That's American history.â 
â 
White American ancestors made life a hell-scape for Black American ancestors for *hundreds of years*, and used that violence to extract untold wealth for themselves. That's American history.â 
â 
White American ancestors used their positions of authority to set-up systems of economics, policing, and education that systematically shrank the opportunities available to anyone who didn't look like them. That's American history.â 
â 
As we wrap up #BlackHistoryMonth I keep thinking on this paradoxical 'celebration': the incredible leadership, discovery and heritage that flows from Black American ancestors was so often in response to the violent, racialized hatred directed at them from white ancestors.â 
â 
So rather than pretending that a February-long 'celebration' will somehow right those historical (and ongoing) wrongs, I choose to see this month as a reminder that only the FUTURE experience of Black people in America will *prove*--or disprove--the reality of the loftiest of American goals: the universal rights to life, liberty, and the pursuit of happiness.â 
â 
To Black history, Black present, and Black futures,â 
Coach @welew_â 
â 
#antiracism #InDefenseOfBlackLives #UnlearnAndRelearn #amplifymelanatedvoices #socialjustice #racialjusticeâ 

Whenever we bring up 'pleasure' in a fitness context, we're bound to get some confused looks.

After all, "no pain, no gain" is still mainstream in gym culture ð¤·â
â 
But training your body (aka #fitness) without tuning into your pleasure means ignoring a pretty key part of how we humans have evolved:

our brains *tend* to go after pleasure, and *tend* to move away from suffering.â 
â 
That's why we LOVE the quote above from one of our Kinstretch Unlimited members, and a bad-ass coach in her own right: @LindsayTunkl

Finding pleasure is not a triviality when your bodily safety is at stake--it's critical.â 
â 
A lot of the on-going challenge that we face living in our bodies--pain, stiffness, limited function--arises when we IGNORE this basic tendancy (and go on repeating painful movements, shunning pleasurable movements, etc).â 
â 
As coaches we see the result of this bodily "conflict of interest" all the time.â 
â 
In fact, usually when we begin working with a new person we need to remind them several times of two basic 'rules' in our approach...â 
â 
âï¸learn to navigate the *pain-free* positions available at your joints (1 joint at a time! #CARs)

âï¸tune into the places, positions, and movements that *feel good*â 
â 
We repeat these tenents of training over and over NOT because the person "can't get it" but actually because that's how it goes with fundamentals!

They need to be *practiced* to become a real, concrete part of your movement vocabulary.â 
â 
But focusing this way is allllllll worth it when your body--feeling safe that you won't expose it (knowingly) to painful movements AND that you're actively 'nourishing' it with some pleasure--starts to reward you with that magical sensation that we've taken to calling #BodyTrustâ 
â 
And when THAT happens, the sky is the limit...â 
â 
So this #FuckItFriday we invite you to

a.) let go of those narratives telling you that your PAIN is not a real alarm bell in your system, and

b.) look for and lean into those ways that *you* access pleasure in *your* body.â 
â 
Happy Friday y'all!â 
â 
- Coach @welew_â 

Love getting a message like this from a client. Especially on their 2nd day back after a year+ of NOT working with us. 

Hilary started with us 3 years (and several lifetimes) ago.

We were running "Small Group Training" out of a big wharehouse-y crossfit gym, sneaking in subte invitations to listen to your body in between the deafening crashes of barbells dropping onto the cement floor.

She was a star student back then, lapping up our approach to fitness, getting stronger, feeling good, and for the first time in her life, sticking with a fitness thing for more than a few months.

We worked together through some major life transitions.

Joy-filled moments like getting married, and having a baby.

Grief-laden times like losing her mother to a devastating illness in the span of 6months.

It was during that time, of tending to her mother in the final days, that she appreciated her physical strength the most:

Of all her family members, she was the only one strong enough to help her mother move when she wanted to change from laying flat to sitting upright.

What a gift.

In October 2019, we moved into our own studio, and between the slightly longer commute, and the new baby schedule, it just wasn't working.

We parted ways at that point, wishing each other well and knowing we had given it our best shot.

A few weeks go, she reached back out saying she was willing to give the online thing a go.

She had tried a BUNCH of stuff, but some of the physical pain that chronically nagged her just wasn't going away.

"I think that working with you all was a critical part of the puzzle for me."

It means the world to us to support folks to feel good, move powerfully, and in turn be able to show up the way they want to in their lives.

We don't pretend that we are the "end-all be-all" movement thang for everyone forever -- our real goal is to give our clients the tools to KNOW THEMSELVES.

To see the "puzzle" and understand what pieces are needed.

Glad to be back on your team, @hillybean 

So proud of you for having your OWN back, and reaching out for the support you need.

We have been encouraging clients to not identify their personal health with their BMI for years...

Recently we had the absolute pleasure of attending a webinar with @virgietovar â which was riveting and magical from start to finish â but the part we want to talk about today is what she shared on the origin story of BMI.

This formula of height and weight was created by Adolphe Quetelet in the 1830s.

He was a statistician, with no medical training, who became interested in applying the ânewâ science of statistics and probability to human behavior.

When tasked with figuring out the relationship between body weight and cardiovascular health outcomes, he came up with this formula to allow scientists to assess the relative health risks of large populations.

There are some key factors that make this research inadmissible by current peer review standards:

1. He only used this formula to collect data from white men.

2. He collected height and weight of a sample size of these men, then found the average height & weight of that sample group, and used THAT to determine what the ânormalâ aka âhealthyâ BMI range is.

Anyone see a problem here?

That would be like deciding the ânormalâ size range for all kinds of trees is 15 feet after only studying Douglas firs.

What about redwoods?
What about oak trees?
What about olive trees?

You get my point here.

The ânormalâ range for BMI is based on a sample size that is not representative of the diversity of human kind.

We invite you to disregard BMI as you see fit, and focus on the things that make you FEEL your best and most healthy 

(taking into account mental & emotional health as well as physical)

Carry on.

#BMIisRacist
#antiracism
#InDefenseOfBlackLives
#UnlearnAndRelearn
#socialjustice
#racialjustice
#EmbraceBodyVariance
#EndWeightStigma
#SmashTheHierarchy

Our goal is to help you become more *effective* at moving how YOU want to move.

Our goal is to help you progressively match--or, *fit*--your personal meat-suit to your imagination; âfitnessâ in this sense is how prepared your tissues are to go after your dreams.

Our goal is to help you ADAPT.

Too often, "fitness" is not focused on adapation at all.

Too often, "fitness" is about acting out the part of "diligent work-er-out-er", and doing what other people deem the "best" or "hardest" workouts.

Too often, "fitness" is about assimilating to some external norm.

Fuck that. Adaptation, not assimilation.

Happy #FuckItFriday y'all!

Think of that person in your life--we all have *at least* one, right?--who talks AT you, and not to you or with you.â 
â 
Maybe they're a sh*t boss who just tells you what to do, or maybe they're a family member who can't stop talking about themselves.â 
â 
They might even be someone who *performs* the 'listening' job pretty convincingly--they have basic head-nods and "uhuh's" down pat--but you can clearly feel that they are *not* hearing you.â 
â 
And no matter the WHY behind their self-centered-ness, the punchline hurts just the same: you are having a one-way conversation, which isn't really a conversation at all.â 
â 
When we look at how our body talks to itself, a 'conversation' is a really useful analogy to help understand how our thoughts (from our ð§ ) are relayed to our bodies, and how our bodies sensations are relayed back to our brain.â 
â 
But very often, that conversation isn't quite as open and equitable as we might like; in fact, much of the time, we tend to have one-way conversations with our bodies.â 
â 
We make demands (without asking for our bodies input), or we get lost in our thoughts and forget that we even *have* these magical meat suits just south of our necks.â 
â 
Or--the worst--we antagonize our bodies, scapegoat them, seeing them as the root of everything that's wrong in our lives.â 
â 
In our experience, *everyone* has moments like this when we are one-way-ing our communication with our bodies.â 
â 
It's just part of being conscious, social animals; sometimes our physical selves simply matter less than everything else, and that is ok.â 
â 
But it's also important to have time when you check in, make that physical side of our reality a real priority, and one worth paying our attention to.â 
â 

Ilya Parker has been and continues to be one of the most important leaders in fitness right now, in our opinion.â 
â 
They were one of the first to help us understand how 'fitness' (as it is often shown and practiced) is *not* inherantly interested in physical health and safety; if it were, it would be much more oriented around the experience of our societies' most marginilized folx.â 
â 
Our on-going learning is the result of Ilya's *effortful* campaign to decolonize mainstream fitness, and that work is too easy (especially via social media) to take freely, without compensation. And despite our best intentions, this info-grab just carries forward the violent history of white folx co-opting the efforts of Black and brown people for their own edification.â 
â 
So while we know our dollars are just a drop in the bucket that Black trans creators and teachers deserve, we make a point to actually pay Ilya for their work when we can. (Links to do so are conveniently in Ilya's profile!)â 
â 
If you have learned from Ilya (or others speaking the truth of what life is like on the margins of our society), please consider compensating them for that labor.â 

I started calling myself a  #RecoveringPerfectionist as a joke.

Which is what I do when things are intense â lighten the mood with a witty turn of phrase that makes everyone around me feel more comfortable.

But as Iâve lived with it, this name, it has become clear to me that perfectionism is incredibly addictive and debilitating, much like any other form of addiction.

It can hijack you.

Even when youâve had a long stretch without any major ârelapsesâ

I realized I was doing myself a disservice by imagining that I would âkick this habit for goodâ

And that it would be kinder and more supportive to create a toolkit for how to bring myself back home when this shit kicks up (which it inevitably will.)

Play has been magical for me.

When that perfectionist mindset is running the show, we can get caught up the âam I doing this right? What if I do it wrong? Best not to do anything at allâ trap.

Play lifts the latch.

When we frame a movement as a game, with clear parameters but no one right answer, and invite our selves to simply play the game.

We free ourselves up to MOVE.

Is there a way that you feel perfectionism keeping you still?

Letâs create a game together to get you moving.

xx,
Coach @hannahhusband

Well helllllo there ðâ 
â 
We thought we'd take a moment to (re) introduce ourselves...â 
â 
We met somewhat serendipitously (thru complicated family/friend ties) in Boston in 2012, where we worked together at a corporate-style gym as personal trainers (Hannah got Will the job ;)
â 
It was a nice vibe, but didn't quiiiiite fit either of us.

After a few years and a couple cross-country moves, we again became colleagues, but this time in Oakland (Will got Hannah the job ;)
â 
And in case anyone is curious, #Oakland is the shit.â 
â 
Then, in 2015, after years of brainstorming we jumped and formed The Fitness Alchemists.â 
â 
We were so excited to help people really tune into themselves, and find *their* strength. And we did!â 
â 
But the more we learned and the more we worked with folx, the more we realized there were TWO gaps in our approach:â 
â 
- most people are deeply disconnected from their physical selvesâ 
- much of that disconnection is driven by faulty societal norms based on fatphobia (which is itself based on ableism and white supremacy)â 
â 
The journey of unpacking these distinct-but-related questions bring us to TODAY:â 
â 
We love coaching people all over the place (all of our coaching is online now) in the magical possibilities of applying a scientifically-sound approach to MOVING and FEELING how *THEY* want to.â 
â 
We're glad that you're here!â 

Do you ever find yourself wondering if the movement (or "exercise" or "workout" etc.) you're doing is... ENOUGH?â 
â 
As in, "hard enough"? or "change-making enough"?â 
â 
These are questions that have dogged me for years, and still do. In many cases, I have spent more time on the wondering then on the actual moving... which is odd ð§ haha.â 
â 
After lots of pondering, and even more hard-just-cuz-it's-hard training, these questions finally dissolved into a bigger one:â 
â 
ð Where do I get my understanding of "enough" from?â 
ð Who or what has determined what is "enough", for *ME*?â 
â 
And while I don't generally have a clear answer to that question, I have come to realize that simply *attempting* to answer it has brought me more movement JOY than any amount of "enough-chasing" ever did.â 
â 
This is because exploring a question like that can only be done by actually moving your body, and beginning to notice your edges.â 
â 
Your experience, after all, is wholly yours.â 
â 
And as I began to explore my edges in this way, to contend with the limits of my strength/endurance/ability/etc, I began to realize that the next step--to nurture and expand those edges--felt like a logical, obvious next step.â 
â 
I also realized that these challenging, physical efforts were actually a joyful experience IF I was truly engaged with noticing, honoring, and expanind my edges. As soon as I just went through the motions, and worked hard to satisfy some external goal, the joy dissolved.â 
â 
So for this #FuckItFriday I want to lift up the idea that challenging, demanding training can be a reflection of YOUR journey, the exploration of YOUR boundaries, and not an attempt at living up some external definition of ENOUGH.â 
â 
Cuz you are already way, way more than ENOUGH.â 
â 

Been having this chat with several clients recently.â 
â 
Itâs such a natural impulse to try to save ourselves from a familiar hurt repeating itself by âbeing careful.ââ 
â 
And while we are all for *being gentle* with yourself at all times, âbeing carefulâ is a strategy that will not serve us.â 
â 
First of all, life is too random and we have way less control than we think we do.

See all of 2020 for reference.â 
â 
Second, if we truly want to becomeï¿¼ More Resilient, to trust ourselves to handle the Random and the Difficult, we must encounter digestible difficulty, regularly and mindfully.â 
â 
Our brilliant bodies have evolved to adapt to stress, such that overtime, little by little, we become able to handle whatever it was that broke us before.â 
â 
Resilience also doesnât happen by foolishly charging into the jaws of the thing that caused our pain without any difference in strategy or preparation.â 
â 
Resilience-building is a gradual process.â 
â 
And weâre here for it. And you.â 

Each week, on Saturdays, we dedicate this platform to a singular mission: anti-racism.â 
â 
We started last June, after George Floyd was murdered by someone sworn to *protect* him.â 
â 
Like many, many others, we were shocked and outraged into action.â 
â 
But as we've learned, that shock and outrage is PART of the very structure that kills people simply for being Black.â 
â 
To see Big Floyd's murder as an outlier, an oddity in an otherwise safe America, would be to ignore 400+ years of indiscriminate violence done on Black bodies.â 
â 
As two people committed to sharing and expanding the joy of having a body, our work is useless if it happens within a society that only allows certain people--white people--to feel safe in their own skin.â 
â 
While we recognize that we are woefully unqualified to lead this fight, we are committed to diving in and grappling with the racial wound that America has never taken the adequate steps to heal.â 
â 
This past week, as we reveled in the sight of the first Black Vice President taking office--and the first woman to be elected to the federal executive branch--we recalled the spirit of John Lewis, quoted above, who our country lost last year.â 
â 
As he showed over nearly 6 decades of activism, the fight against racism is not about making nice or smoothing over.â 
â 
It's about speaking up, interrupting inequity, and seeing actions through.â 
â 
#antiracismâ 
#InDefenseOfBlackLivesâ 
#UnlearnAndRelearnâ 
#amplifymelanatedvoicesâ 
#socialjusticeâ 
#racialjustice

Look around and you will see that change--in all realms--happens in two distinct ways:â 
â 
â¬from the top, working downâ 
â«from the bottom, working upâ 
â 
The changes that happen as a result, and the ways those changes happen, vary significantly depending on the direction of action.â 
â 
In either case, the change will align with the interests of those who instigate that change...â 
â 
â¬When change in our society happens from the top, it neccessarily reflects the interests and understanding of those *at the top*.â 
â«When it happens from the bottom, it instead reflects the collaborative--and messy--process of those *at the bottom* coming together.â 
â 
The power inherent to that second approach--the grass-roots approach--flows from the ability of the whole group to overlap, argue, organize, and finally coordinate each of their individual perspectives and unique powers.

*More* diversity, more variability, makes the collective much, much stronger.â 
â 
It's the same in our bodies.â 
â 
When all of the changes happen from the "top" and work "downward", we are operating under the (false) idea that there is some sort of commander, sitting in our brain and directing our actions.â 
â 
But the reality is much more democratic.

All of our conscious sensations, movements and even emotions are the result of how our brain interpretes all of the incoming data from our nervous system, each nerve a 'voter' in the ecosystem of our body.â 
â 
And where does the vast majority of information about movement come into our brains FROM...?

Our joints.â 
â 
This is why we are so adamant about focusing and working on joints.

When we tune into what they are truly feeling, and nurture them in the way they are asking for, the result is a stronger, more-informed and more cohesive body-politic.â 
â 
Some food for thought during this Inauguration Week (in America).â 
â 
- Coach @welew_â 

title:
We just wanted to drop this reminder in the midst of ALL the BS youâll see on social media in January about 'shredding', 'sculpting', and 'blasting' fat.

Tho, who am I kidding?âbody fat gets a bad rap all year round.

Stigma around this extraodinary part of our bodies is a rampant and harmful part of our culture, and is one of the ways that our fellow humans are oppressed on a daily basis.

I didn't quite get this through my head until I actually started listening to people who experience harmful anti-fat bias from their family, "friends", colleagues, and even their doctors. And the stories I hear are astoundingly awful.

The more I learn, the more I realize that this incessant, devastating narrative that 'fat people' are somehow morally corrupt hasn't just materialized out of thin air.

In fact, it's the continuation of a centuries-old effort to frame certain folx as less-than (and therefore 'deserving' of their abuse) and others as 'correct'.

Just like racism--and with shared roots--many of the cultural ideas today about body fat (and people who have visible fat on their body) were conjured up as a *means* of control/coercion/domination, a justification, and not as the natural result of 'fatness'.

Cuz fat is an incredible, essential part of our bodies, remember?

- Coach @welew_

That beautiful tree you've been eyeing only invites you to climb it when your shoulders can entertain the idea of reaching overhead.â 
â 
Same goes for that trail, or that sport, or that ANYthing.â 
â 
Our world shrinks or expands based on what our bodies feel safe to reach for.â 
â 
If knees don't bend, the floor starts to feel very far away.â 
â 
Our work is to help you tend to your body in such a way that each joint (knees, shoulders, every vertebrae of your spine) can open, close, twist, and bend in all the ways that serve your adventurous life.â 
â 
You choose the adventure, we will help you get your tools ready for the journey.â 
â 
We will work with the body that you have today, respecting what is possible, and slowly, as the body is willing, we will expand that circle of possibility.â 
â 
This pic is a throwback to winter 2019 when coach @hannahhusband got to go adventuring on Maui and decided to try an aerial inversion on a tree branch because... WHY NOT?â 

This idea is a major roadblock for sooooo many folx I work with.

Fixated on âmeasurablesâ and looking for simple ways to know how their body is changing (or not), many people tend to gravitate toward the easiest-to-measure metricsâ¦

â¦like what you weigh, or how many reps you did, or what kind of weight is on the bar.

But as Goodhart says (not sure who that is actually ð , just appreciate their âlawâ), beginning to skew your training toward those EXTERNAL measures *always* makes them crappier measures of anything really important (like your health, strength, or satisfactionâall complex, hard-to-measure qualities most of us are trying to improve).

Instead, we need to âkeep the goal the goalâ and focus on using our training to guide *long-term, systemic* improvement.

That also means we need to let measures be exactly what they areâindications of progressâwithout becoming our actual training.

I used to ascribe my sense of self-worth to how much weight I could lift, and it just about broke me. ðââï¸

Whatâs a sh*tty measure that youâve pledged allegiance to in the past?

#ThinkyThursday
#AllBodiesAreGoodBodies
#BefriendYourBody
#FunctionalRangeSystems
#MakeShitWorkNice

Coaching humans is an excellent way to figure out what cues and concepts connect with people, and which donât.

This lil number above stumbled out of me a while back, and made someoneâs eyes light up with understanding.

It mightâve been the first time they realized that âfeelingâ was a crucial component to prompting their body to change (the goal of training).

So I used the phrase again, with someone else. And then again, and again, always gauging how it landed, and how it was best delivered.

Little by little, I uncovered another precious coaching *nugget*, something honed over time, sharpened by interacting with real people.

This is one of my favorite parts of the craft of coaching movement: how much language matters, and how tangible that language can become as actual movement, in actual bodies.

And you shouldn't treat it--or MOVE it--like it is.
--
So many avenues to getting movement into your life are geared around 'giving you a good workout'...as if moving with intent and verve and joy is only something that someone ELSE can "do" to you, or for you (they can't).

As if your body was just another widget to be optomized into conformity. Or, another *commodity* to be managed out of site, out of mind.

I don't use this particular language lightly, because I believe that the same "wheels of progress" (aka a strictly capitalist ethic) that gradually works to diminish the emobodied, physical experience of being a human into bite-size "workout$" also gets applied when...

â¡ï¸ big corporations gradually squeeze the middle class out of opportunity
â¡ï¸ first-world countries outsource the shadow of their economy to the billions of people and communities world-wide that experience constant food and shelter insecurity.
â¡ï¸ systemic, structural hierarchies reflecting racial and xenophobic bias get sustained year after year, in the face of centuries of heroic resistance

This is not new, and these are not my ideas... my view is one provided by the legions of deep thinkers who have come before... but all of this ð is ALSO the logic that convinced white Europeans to systematically inculcate themselves with the devastating myth of white supremacy and Black inferiority.

It's a logic that prioritizes profit and progress over the humanity of real humans, and it's alive and well in 2022.

These days, I see it at work (among other places) in the disembodying language and marketing of the mainstream #fitness industry.

Language that incessantly pushes changing the size of your body, how you LOOK to other people, over and above any other goal. Language that I used to use myself, and used to believe in. #ImSorry

You--and your body--are so much more than a commodity to be managed away.

#antiracism
#InDefenseOfBlackLives
#UnlearnAndRelearn
#amplifymelanatedvoices
#socialjustice
#racialjustice

title:
Effective training/coaching is NOT about being told what to do, or even how to do it.

Itâs actually about guiding someone in the never-ending process of FEELING themselves more clearly.

That's what the coaching is alllll about inside our online membership, and what you're seeing in the slides above ... I'm here to help orient you toward yourSELF more clearly, more directly. #TaskDesigner

The ability to accurately feel the contractions in our body is a long and winding road, involving many unforeseen bumps in the road, as well stunning moments of epiphany. We are *humans* after all ð .

But we do this so that *training*, the pursuit of measurably improved body function, can actually be done. So that we can move through injury and pain, and grow our bodies to support our dreams. #InfiniteGame

But without the ability to feel into ourselves, we're lost; we end up throwing any/all random drills (external training), and usually TOO many of them, in our own way to try to ellicit any sign of progressive, positive change. Training in this random and medium-ish-intensity always *ends*, at some point, with stagnation--injury, plateau, or distraction. #HayflickLimit

Luckily there are specific ways to work on â feeling yourself â, and thatâs exactly whatâs going on in with that TFA member above. This client came to me with a long history of shoulder pain, alongside a tendency to push through and past that pain to find the kind of *movement* that he loved.

Untying that knot with him has been slow and steady,  and we HAD to start by improving his ability to *feel* his tissues. Only then could we start training him back to the kind of physicality he wants in his life.

#ClientSpotlight
#AlchemistsAtPlay
#TFAMemberExperience
#BodyLiberation
#BodyTrust
#BefriendYourBody
#LiveByFeel
#LearnByFeel
#FindYourJoy

title:
This is always important to remember, whether you're just getting started with building a movement practice, or you have a nicely seasoned approach. Change simply cannot and does not happen without STRESS.

Now ... of course there are caveats here. Like if you're already in a state of chronic stress, and you simply think *adding* a stressful workout to the system will magically make the background life stressors feel easy (hint: it won't).

And this is why Kathy Sierra ( @pantherflows on IG ) talks about incorporating more down-regulating methods ('calming') ALONGSIDE up-regulating methods ('stress') to help *her* movers--who are horses--get moving.

But what is non-negotiable is that there must be some clear prompt (aka stress) for your body-system to change, some signal for it to organize around, if it is to make ANY change. In fact, one of the biggest pitfalls I see with human movers (and what Kathy talks about in her work), is actually making the movement 'ask' TOO easy for the mover.

If your strategy is always to make the 'ask' easier in the face of resistance, and not lean into the stressor a little bit, you will pretty quickly make like Kathy's horses and simply not care much about it anymore. Because the ask has been whittled down to something that just doesn't matter. ð¤·ââï¸

And last thing? Kathy Sierra is SO COOL, and her work is mega-interesting and inspiring to me (remember, she trains horses! and I know almost nothing about horses! but the overlaps between our worlds are spooky and amazing). Thanks to @hathaequus for helping me really see and feel this connection!

#MotivationMonday
#MakeShitWorkNice
#MovementScience
#EcologicalDynamics
#NonlinearPedagogy
#AllBodiesAreGoodBodies
#BefriendYourBody

I can listen to the nuanced ways that coaches distill information for *their* athletes ALL. DAY. LONG.

There is something so essentially human behind the particulars of good 'coaching communication' tactics, and I love it.

Even the most inexperienced personal trainer realizes pretty quickly how impactful the words (choice, sequence, etc) used to describe and cue a drill can be on the literal movements your clients make.

But take this insight through the kind of career that @_stevekerr_ has had, and set it loose among some of the most high-level athletes in the world (the @Warriors ) and you have the mix for some truly special communication strategies to develop.

So when he dropped this little gem describing his approach to basketball mid-conversation with Jon Stewart (which is great, you can find it on YouTube) I immediately jotted it down.

As Coach Kerr unpacks the idea with Jon, it's clear that he's taken great care to find the *right* words to convey a complex idea--about balance and liberty within a structure--quickly and effectively to his team.

But I guess his motto resonated so quickly with me really because, after watching an unhealthy amount of Warriors basketball over the past few years, I can fully attest that this is *exactly* how the Warriors play: Fast, Loose, and Disciplined.

...and it's breath-taking to watch, especially with @klaythompson back ð! What a great start to this next chapter...

#GoDubs

title:
Ahhh, these lovely beings.

Beyond being a 'cat' or 'dog' or '_____' person, I'm a hang-out-with-fellow-nervous-systems person.

I'm a connections person.

And wooooo-y have Georgie (the darker one) and Bruce taught me a lot about connections over the last 22 months of the Covid-ization of our world.

One of the many things that strikes me about them is how *unique* they are, how different from each other, how varied.

Their coloration, their personalities, their sounds, and especially their sizes. (Bruce is about twice the size of Georgie)

Yes, they are both cats, but in almost all other ways they're diverse creatures, and that intrinsic variation is *everything*.

It influences how they navigate the world, and how they leave their little, paw-shaped mark on it. ð¾

It's their magic.

And it's a lesson us humans would do well to learn!

Body variance is not just a normal thing, but a magnificent, fundamental thing.

So today (and hell, this whole month!) I invite you to give a big #FuckItFriday to all the voices that shout at us to conform, to be the same, to NOT vary. Thanks, but NO THANKS.

Gonna go give Bruce a belly-rub now...

#AllBodiesAreGoodBodies

#HAES
#InclusiveFitness

reÂ·lent (/rÉËlent/)â 
verbâ 
 - abandon or mitigate a harsh intention or cruel treatmentâ 
â 
***â 
Amidst all those moments of striving, of pushing, of imagining *more* (...aka the way that culture tells us is the only way to succeed)...â 
â 
Sometimes all we really need is to RELENT.â 
â 
Striving to be "relentless" feels like one of those fitness-y battle-crys that tricks us into thinking that there's ONE right way to be.â 
â 
But we humans cycle and flow--like the rest of the known universe--and we absolutely cannot always be "relentless", no matter how loud our trainer yells at us.â 
â 
So let yourself settle into the 'What Is' and not only fixate on 'What Isn't' or 'What Should Be' or even 'What Could Be'. These windmills in our minds can suck all of our juice for actual action, and leave us drained and confused.â 
â 
But when we can imagine 'What Is' for ourselves, in all it's imperfect richness, we can actually forgive some of those Not Enough's, and begin to see -- and celebrate -- different-ness in ourselves AND the humans and beings all around us.â 
â 
That's called #Compassion and our world sure needs some of that right now.â 
â 
So sometimes (like maybe on a #Saturday ?)....I encourage you to Relent.â 
â 
Give up the fight, in this moment, and live from that place where you're *already* Doing a Great Job.â 
â 
Go ahead, try it. See what you find.â 
â 
I'm feeling pretty inspired by @alokvmenon these days. Thank you ALOK for giving the world your incredible voice, and helping me see a path forward.â 
â 
#BefriendYourBodyâ 
#MondayMotivationâ 
#BodyLiberationâ 
#AllBodiesAreGoodBodiesâ 
#Fitnessâ 
#CompassionAndComprehension

title:
A Mobility Mood Board for you (can that be a thing?) .... here are few slides that capture (sorta) where my head's been at these days, training-wise.

@marliecouto came by the KinLab last week and we got to film a bunch of @Kinstretch classes for the Library.

It was a total body-nerd fest, and a lot of fun (tho I wasn't the one doing 5 sets of pushups for the "Push It Real Good" class...ð¤ª).

The first vid is her feeling into how her shoulder blades love to 'go along' with her spine during cat/cow....feeling the difference between those movement possibilities ('scapula' v 'spine') is hard, but juicy and full of possibility. ð

Which got me thinking about Chaos Theory again (slide 2), which helps me understand how seemingly unlimited variation actually conforms to a sort of coherence all around us, everyday (and definitely in our brain-body connection). These looping lines are all different, and map different 'paths' through the possible option-space, but they are NOT random by any means; they conform to constraints that dicatate the size and shape formed by repeated 'solutions' to the task. ð¤

Slide 3 shows the shoulder (GH) structures, especially the capsule, that actually 'recieve' the inputs of training and then relay that mechanical information to the brain. If we can gradually diminish the internal contraint of joint immobility, we can 'solve' movement tasks in more ways (essentially, imagine larger loops in the 2nd slide ð).

Slide 4: There is unfathomable variation available within each of us, if only we can tap into it, and develop it. Magically (but also quite scientifically) our internal world follows the same principles that we see at work in the external world, in situations like weather and flocks of birds. In each instance, it is the *variation*, the differences between the parts, that contribute to the overall health of the whole.

Fat doesn't cry.

Sweat is not a measure of how "hard" you are working

{ 2 people of equivalent fitness levels doing the same workout will sweat different amounts because #BodyVarianceIsNormal }

Sweating is simply the main strategy our bodies use to regulate core temperature.

And also: fuck Anti-Fatness in fitness memes (and all places.)

The widely unquestioned myth that exercise is "for" fat loss is a) scientifically untrue and b) really alienating and harmful to people in larger bodies who are regularly shamed into exercising for the sole purose of "losing weight."

Exercise has been claimed as a tool of body opression for too long.

We need to reclaim it for team #AllBodiesAreGoodBodies

â¨Movement is MEDICINE for our bodies. â¨

It can help usâ¦

...relieve stress (by completing the stress cycle)

...improve joint health & function (by nourishing your connective tissues)

...get strong AF (by increasing the load bearing capacity of muscle tissue)

...improve mood (scientists have varied perspectives on WHY this works, but there's lots of evidence correlating mood elevation/ reduced depression & anxiety with regular exercise)

...stoke self-confidence (by helping you feel embodied, present, and powerful)

and NONE OF THESE BENEFITS are dependant on fat loss.

ðread that again. Iâll wait.

Thatâs right, my friends, there are scientifically backed benefits to exercise that have nothing to do with losing weight.

If you see these anti-fat memes going around, and you have some bandwidth, CLAP BACK and let folks know in the comments that anti-fatness is a deeply harmful form of opression.

Especially if you are straight-sized, please take some action to educate folks about the harmful nature of fatphobia this holiday season.

in devotion to body liberation for all,
Coach @HannahHusband

title:
Size variance is normal.

There is no moral value to being "smaller" or "bigger."

[Although much of the wealth of the fitness + diet industry is extracted from the wound caused by this very idea]

There is great value to us as a collective if we can see body VARIANCE as an asset to team humanity.

There *are* places where folks generally embrace difference. Everyone can agree that it's handy to have...
...different sizes of drill bits for different jobs
...different sizes of tupperware for leftovers
...different sized vehicles for city living, vs hauling furniture

There are also places where we all agree that variance adds aesthetic value. Everyone can agree that it's beautiful to see...
...many colors in a sunset
...many shapes of tree in a forest
...many different flowers in a bouquet

So why don't we all agree that different sizes of bodies are also valuable and beautiful?

I know most of the people who follow us are probably nodding along to this, cuz y'all are rad and are doing your work.

My ask for you, if this post resonates, is that you consider sharing it with someone who isn't yet hip to the #bodypositive idea that size variance is a natural, beautiful part of human expression.

Or that you share one of these slides in your stories.

Let's start some conversations, yeah?
- Coach @HannahHusband

My girlfriend recently had a rough knee injury, serious enough to essentially disable her for a few weeks, which prompted us to seek out one of those shower stools that would let her (you guessed it) sit down in the shower.â 
â 
We turned getting one into an epic Friday Night Target Date Night Extravaganza (...but that's another story).â 
â 
Now, at first when we had it, I would gingerly step around it as I showered, maybe subconsciously sensing that 'it wasn't for me'.â 
â 
But after we had it for a week or so, I started using it. And I didn't stop.â 
â 
I'd rest my leg on it to wash my toes, or stretch my hips, or just, you know....take a shower sitting down.â 
â 
It was great.â 
â 
Even though the stool wasn't *for* me--and it literally was making showering POSSIBLE for my lady--it only served to improve my environment.â 
â 
And it got me thinking about how unconscious our environment becomes to us when it *fits* us, when it *works* for us.â 
â 
Compared to the way the world looks when it is NOT made for you, when your body and abilities were not considered in the design, and you are forced to fight for a solution for yourself.â 
â 
I guess this #FuckItFriday post is just to say....I wish that the world was less able-ist, and a bit more appreciative of the ways that people with disabilities can show all of us how to make our world fit all of us a little (or a lot) better.â 
â 
Oh, and to post a photo of my thigh on the 'Gram... cuz s*x sellz ð¤·ââ 
â 
- @welew_â 

Or: doing hard shit feels good.

I have found this to be true for every single human I have ever worked with.

The key is to find what 'challenging' means in each person's context. 'Exertion' might be standing up from a chair, without your hands. Or it might be standing up with a 400 pound barbell on your back. Exertion might look like 2 week-long backpacking trips, or 2 min of sustained running for the first time in your adult life.

Seeing something difficult--especially something with a clear physical/movement component--through to it's conclusion, and surviving, is a reminder of our innate power.

And when you realize that power in the context of activites that you love? You make gold (at least according to your brain/memory).

You have minted a small but mighty memory of *enjoying* the sensation of effort and exertion, and this quickly adds up (just as your physical capacity gradually grows with repeated physical inputs).

Finding the THING (activity, sport, question, pursuit, etc) that makes you want to do it a little *more* every time you try is like discovering a super-powerâ¦

â¦called Intrinsic Motivation

- Coach @welew_

title:
What you're looking at is a visual depiction of how I think about training humans about/with movement.

As part of the Wellness Industry, we see everyday how our work intersects with one of the most important relationships that a human has: the one with their body.

It can be the source of some of life's greatest joys, but having a body can be a fraught and challenging thing at times, too.

For some people, their bodies rarely feel like a safe place to be.

This realization is part of what keeps bringing me back like a clarion-call to those three simple words--Black Lives Matter--and thinking about how I can live out that intention in my work.

Because unless we acknowledge openly, in our lives and in our work, that such a statement is *critical* in our day and age, we are bound to be complicit in the mechanisms that made the sovereignty of Black lives even a question in the first place.

This is why we intentionally center Body Liberation, the Sovereignty of Subjective Experience, and Agency in our training. They are literally the reason we exist as a company.

â¦not to teach squats, or mobility exercises, or help you improve at a sport or competitive pursuit. Those are all just means to an end, an external manifestation of internal change.

In my opinion, it's the internal shift, toward feeling more at home in your body, that is the critical WHY behind doing any sort of physical training at all.

But it's also at the center of what is taken from people when they are oppressed, which is why we want to help bring more of these things to the world:

ð Body Liberation
ð Sovereignty of Subjective Experience
ð Agency

Swipe for a zoomed-in view of how the movement components of our approach feed the internal, psycho-emotional shifts.

- @welew_

You know when someone says something, and from the very first moment you hear it, you know that their words apply on many different levels all at once?â 
â 
It's a transcendant thing, an epiphany of language, and its magic definitely relies on some degree of chance: it has to hit you at the right moment, when YOU're ready for it.â 
â 
But when it does...it just *feels* good to learn about the world this way.â 
â 
That experience pretty much summed up my recent dive into the @posturalrestoration universe (I took the Postural Respiration home-study course).â 
â 
At each turn, as they described the function of all of the systems within our rib cage that work together to BOTH allow us to breath AND to *create* our posture ...ð¤¯...I found myself lingering on these nuggets of insight that Ron Hruska and James Anderson (the presenters) would distill for us, like the one above.â 
â 
On one level, 'moving back' before you can move forward is basically an adage (two steps forward, one step back). But this clichÃ© blossoms with meaning when you learn that the ABILITY to move your ribs BACK (and therefore to be able to *breath* into your back) is essential to our ability to locomote, or MOVE FORWARD.â 
â 
For a topic as familiar and yet eerily-alien as the *anatomy of our trunk*, their combination of precise language, careful layering of concepts, and wide lense of focus  meant that they sounded more like poets than lecturers to me.â 
â 
And their lessons will stick with me longer for it.â 
â 
This willingness to use the tools of Art in service of deeper understanding about complex topics is music to my ears. #inspiredâ 
â 
- Coach @welew_â 

That moment when... you realize your day got away from you, and your body is craving more movement than you've been able to give it.

But you still have to put away the groceries because #Adulting

My first impulse was to try to put them away as quickly as possible, so I could "save time" for a short training session AFTER.

Then I was like, hold up.

Instead of rushing, let's SLOW DOWN, and make this chore a physical game.

So I tried to be as  i n e f f e c i e n t  as possible.

ð¡Put the bag on the floor, NOT close to the pantry.

ð¡Pick up only one object at a time. 
Try to stay on one foot for as long as possible. #BalanceFunTimez

ð¡Try to use a foot for something I would normally do with a hand. [Minds out of the gutter, plz, AHEM]

ð¡Take as few steps as possible. 

Before I knew itâ¦

I was moving curiously

I was having fun [sound on to hear my crack myself up]

and then POOF my groceries were put away.

I know we have a curious crowd of movers following this account -- I'm excited to hear what other variations on this theme y'all come up with.

Please share in the comments and let's inspire each other to infuse more movement games into our choresies.

xo,
Coach @hannahhusband

The mellow morning light.â 
â 
A cuppa coffee to warm things up.â 
â 
And a new shape to my CARs practice.â 
â 
A buncha things shifted around in the last few months, and now most days I'm doing my CARs with my sweetheart @debbbbiee as we sip our coffee.â 
â 
We talk a bit, and always listen to great tunes (just not too uptempo!). But it wasn't a habit that was preplanned or *imposed*.â 
â 
We just drifted into it, and noticed that it was ... really, really nice ð.â 
â 
See, I don't do my CARs the same all the time, and I don't recommend that any one should.â 
â 
We are HUMANs, after all, inconsistent and non-linear. It's part of our magic.â 
â 
Instead of any sort of rigid plan, these kind of serendipitious 'habits' tend to surface when you simply name and *hold* an intention ("I would like to nourish my joints with a little attention and movement *every day*"), while staying open to alllllll the ways that such an intention might/could show up in your life.â 
â 
Not forcing, but letting it in. â 
â 
There's no ONE right way--and the path *will* change over time, and we need to let it.â 
â 
Day by day, the actual behavior you're after (like CARs) will vary a bit, and that's ok! That's why it's a Practice, and not a Performance.â 
â 
But over time certain patterns emerge, and hidden inside can be some of life's sweetest treasure.â 
â 

How often do you move how YOU want to?â 
â 
So many of us have gotten so much pressure to move in particular ways. For particular purposes, not chosen by us.â 
â 
Raise your hand if you can relate?â 
â 
If you've done Kinstretch with us, you've felt how SPECIFIC we are with our cueing -- move THIS, not THAT. That kind of precision is what helps us train the tissue we want to strengthen, which is how we open up new pathways and options for how to move.â 
â 
I'll be really honest -- I don't always LIKE doing Kinstretch. But I really like how it frees me up to move,  explore, and allow my body to make shapes and patterns at her whim.â 
â 
Dancing like this, at sunset, with no agenda but to feel good and respond to my desires immediately with motion, reminded me that THIS IS WHAT IT IS ALL ABOUT.â 
â 
The training is not the point. It's just the tool to help you get free.â 
â 
This doen't mean the training doesn't matter -- we have to offer specific inputs if we want specific adaptations.â 
â 
But it's so easy to get lost in the details. To get into that headspace of winning the "doing it the most right" race.â 
â 
So if you haven't in a while, I dare ya:â 
Treat yourself to a little free movement. Throw the rule book out the window, and let pleasure be your guide.â 
â 
xo,â 
Coach @HannahHusbandâ 
â 
P.S. You get to decide what "free" is for you -- there are no wrong answers!â 

title:
I need to tell you about an important new project unfolding in East Oakland: Power The People.

(Bay Area peeps in particular, listen up!)

This project is all about creating a better, easier, and safer corridor through East Oakland to allow residents of these communities to gain access to the beautiful Martin Luther King Jr. Shoreline Park. As I learned today, biking around with some of the residents of these rich and historic communities of color, many of these folx have never ventured across the freeway to the stretch of bay shoreline that glitters so close.

The richness of this kind of green space, and the sensual relaxation that it offers, is sorely missed in many of the neighboring communities that have, for so long, housed the most toxic industries while receiving the least portion of community care and collective support.

And serving as an immediate and obvious example of this environmental injustice, the literal route to get from one side of East Oakland to the other is about as challenging to navigate--by any means--as I can imagine: fast/bad traffic, few bike lanes, exhaust-filled air, potholes, glass, etc etc. Safe is the last way I would describe it.

So the @EastOaklandCollective organized a bike ride this morning *thru* this problem. Led by reps from several local organziations, about 40 of us bikers met up at Liberation Park and moved en masse (and v safely ð) thru the neighborhoods, across the industrial areas, over the on-ramps and railroad tracks, and into the peace of the shoreline.

Today, as we all biked together to the Bay, I was so aware of how mobility--the literal ability to move around your world--is inextricably linked to the ways that we are able to form the communities that determine the quality of our lives.

The ride was part of the larger Power the People initiative which is spearheaded by the brilliant minds at @EastOaklandCollective . I really recommend checking it out whether you live nearby or not--it's a super interesting project (a google search will get you there ð).

- @welew_

I wish we lived in a world where this was a known fact.â 
â 
But that isn't the current reality.â 
â 
I hear the terms "fat" and "fit" used as though they are a binary -- like you can only be one or the other.â 
â 
Since we have the word âFitnessâ in our name, I want to make sure that we are crystal clear about a couple of things:â 
â 
âFitnessâ describes a state of readiness to perform physical tasks.â 
â 
It might include having enough strength, stamina, range of motion, and joint health to engage in the physical activities that are meaningful to you. â 
â 
All of these qualities can be cultivated through physical training, and *are not tied* to body size or weight or body composition.â 
â 
Having fat on your body doesnât take away your fitness or define your value in any way.â 
â 
Nor is fitness the price you have to pay for carrying fat on your body.â 
â 
The cultural conceit that a body is EITHER fat OR fit ignores so much nuance, is scientifically untrue, and continues to prop up the oppressive fatphobic notion that smaller bodies are "better" than larger ones.â 
â 
"Fit" comes in many shapes, sizes, forms, and expressions and will ALWAYS be relative to the individual. â 
â 
Happy #FuckItFriday y'all.â 
â 
- Coach @HannahHusbandâ 

In some very real, concrete (and dirt and asphalt ð¤£) ways I have fallen in love with the Earth from the back of a bicycle.â 
â 
When I was kid, riding my prized Trek mountain bike to 7th grade with my trumpet strapped on the back, the bike was my ticket to ride, my badge of freedom, my route to autonomy and independance.â 
â 
When I was a heartbroken 20-year-old college kid, I nursed a bad break-up riding up the foggy, picturesque slopes of Tunnel Rd in the North Oakland hills, over and over.â 
â 
When Covid hit, I found a way to finally exhale by taking my frustration out for long, slow rides around Contra Costa County.â 
â 
Riding a bike is one of the clearest ways of feeling your own power. The way that this power is amplified by the ingenuity of a simple, mechanical machine only adds to the magic.â 
â 
Which is why I'm such a big fan of what Cycles of Change does in East Oakland (and their shop! @oaklandbikery ) teaching and empowering kids--of all ages and backgrounds--to grab hold of a couple wheels and see what's out there.â 
â 
Thanks for kicking ass and leading the way!â 
â 
We just donated (again) at < cyclesofchange.org >... will you? (or donate a bike? or volunteer?)â 
â 

"Perceiving beauty is a skill set. If someone else doesn't see your beauty, that doesn't mean you aren't beautiful, it means their skill set isn't very well developed yet."â 
â 
@RagenChastain said this during the Q & A in one of her monthly online workshops and it planted like a seed in my belly.â 
â 
We've been raised on a very narrow standard of beauty. And we have been raised to believe it's normal to judge and compare our appearance with others.â 
â 
These two pillars of culture have harmed so. many. people.â 
â 
It's high time we widened the horizon of what we consider beautiful so that every human has a seat at that table.â 
â 
Here's one way I have been working on developing my perceiving beauty skill set. [Credit to Emily Nagoski @enagoski for this exercise]:â 
â 
â¡ï¸When you notice yourself noticing someone else's body or appearance, interrupt whatever thought you might be having -- especially if it's a judgemental one--and instead say "aren't they beautiful!"â¡ï¸â 
â 
It'll feel weird and artificial at first. Becuase we are conditioned to assciate the word "beautiful" with only a handful of visual traits.â 
â 
It gets less weird over time, as your brain begins to associate more bodies as "beautiful."â 
â 
Let's widen our lenses, my friends.â 
â 
xo,â 
Coach @HannahHusbandâ 

Ahhh yes, the Kinetic Stretch... easy to love, easy to hate ð.

This exercise is really just a process we can use to get better at moving INTO and OUT of *any* end-range position.

And what makes it so hard is NOT big external weights (there are none), and NOT the quickness of the movement (it's slow AF)â¦

What makes it hard is the demand on our ability to FOCUS internally, on what we FEEL, and asking those tissues to engage.

This clip is a from a recent class we released to our members focused on building the capacity of your 'surfing muscles', aka the INTERNAL structures that allow your body to -- you guessed it -- surf!

But as any of you who give this drill a try will realize, making INTERNAL structures better at contracting, lengthening, and being controlled generally will have wide-ranging impacts on ANY activity that involves squats or squat-resembling positions.

This is one reason why we're such big fans of Kinstretch as a part of really *any* body's movement practice.

Because no matter what movements you want to DO or MAKE or BE with your body...

...you'll definitively be able to DO THAT better if you improve the internal structures that actually make movement *happen*.

ð¥ð¤©WIN-sation alert!ð¤©ð¥â 
â 
This client is describing the very personal win-sation* of unlocking a long-lost movement. â 
*sensation + winâ 
â 
In this case, she is describing suddenly feeling hip flexion, aka when your thigh bone comes towards your chest, as part of the motion of walking.â 
â 
She started with us with the goal of getting stronger, and reducing âincidents of back pain/tightness and hip tightness/pain.â <âHer exact words.â 
â 
In her virtual 1-1 Kinstretch sessions + home program, weâve been focusing on buildingâ 
- spinal awareness and mobilityâ 
- hip strength (at end range of motion)â 
â 
We found in her assessment that though her hips often FEEL tight, she has plenty of flexibility in that joint. â 
â 
Her hips *can stretch* in any direction needed for a hip, but they werenât STRONG enough to move into those full ranges under their own control. And so the tightness persisted, no matter how much time she spent stretching.â 
â 
After a few months of dedicated strengthening at end range, the tightness is easing up and more freedom of motion is showing up like a delightful surprise in every-day actions.â 
â 
We absolutely love these moments!â 
â 
They remind us why we do what we do:â 
â 
We help peopleâ¦â 
Compassionately communicate with their bodiesâ 
Reclaim and integrate lost or painful partsâ 
Strengthen and fortify each part, to unlock possibilities for the wholeâ 

I think images of people sleeping is beautiful.â 
â 
The blissful refusal of the world around them, the clear and present 'No', is such a true act. Genuine and absent of pretense or motive.â 
â 
It's a big 'fuck you' to everyone's agenda, including your own, which opens your door to ... well, the whole world.â 
â 
Or as Jenny Odell (@jennitaur and fellow Oakland-er!) relays in her incredible book (How to Do Nothing), quoting Pilvi Takala: "The potential of nothing is everything."â 
â 
Incredibly, each of us already do this refusal-by-resting every day, when we *sleep*.

It's not something we have to 'learn how to do', but actually something that takes unlearning, remembering, inviting, unblocking.â 
â 
We all hold that mammalian wisdom of HOW to sleep, wihtout a single conscious thought as to how it happens, as it happens.â 
â 
We all 'know' (at some deep, animal level) how to loosen our grip on everything, to set down the need for control long enough to step over the threshold into sleep.â 
â 
Knowing rationally that our bodies need that medicine is one thing, actually taking the steps to provide yourself with that rest is quite another.â 
â 
Or as @thenapministry repeats, over and over, like a beautiful prayer: 'Lay yo ass down.'â 
â 
Certainly sleep is not the *only* way to rest ... in fact, you can rest whenever you choose, even if only for a few moments.â 
â 
Stare at the birds, or the wall.â 
Just sit with your partner or kid or colleague or friend or stranger.â 
Touch your feet.â 
â 
Refuse a motive, and rest.â 
â 
I am forever grateful for Tricia Hersey and her incredible work (www.TriciaHersey.com) to help me realize some of these anti-rest patterns at work in my own life.

Rest really can be a form of resistance to white supremacy and economies of exploitation.â 
â 
What a world this might be if we could all rest enough.â 
â 
- Coach @welew_â 
â 

We are interested in changing the conversation about fitness.â 
â 
With how deeply you can effect the experience of living your life by judiciously applying the tools of the trade, 'fitness' has the promise of helping each one of us get closer and closer to who we *really* are, and how we want to live.â 
â 
But so often that intention is squandered on shame-fueled, anti-body hormonal (and emotional) slug-fests that leave you feeling buzzed right now, but broken tomorrow.â 
â 
So if we're going to change fitness we need to talk about what works and how to do it, but also...â 
â 
...WHY are you doing it?â 
...WHY is moving your body important, for you?â 
...WHAT do you *like* about moving your body?â 
...WHAT feels good?â 
...HOW can you get more of that good-good, and less of the b.s.?â 
â 
Coming to these questions has been a long and winding road, but it's so meaningful to get messages like the one above from fellow movement nerds ð¤©.â 
â 
Because along with all the nuts-and-bolts of being a human, there are some pretty important components that have nothing to do with cells or ROM or motor units, but are about helping people find *meaning* in their movement.â 
â 
Thanks so much for tuning in @jamieplaysoutside and I'm so glad that it resonates!â 
â 
Part of the beauty of this craft is how deeply important each of our takes is; we all resonate slightly differently ð» â 
â 
In turn thanks to all the wonderful folx who inspire us each day, like @laura.beth.wenger @decolonizing_fitness @thenapministry @mosesbernard and too many more for IG to handle ð¡ .â 
â 
I'm curious ... Who else should we be listening to who works on #BodyLiberation?â 

There are many brilliant coaches out there, but your messaging resonates perfectly with my heart and what I think people need to hear. SUPER inspired by and learning from you!"]â 

I bet you've had the experience of arriving in a new place and NOT speaking the local language.â 
â 
Even if you know a few phrases, or recognize some landmarks, the sensation is supremely disorienting, especially if you need to quickly navigate, communicate or really, DO anything.â 
â 
Leaving aside the *benefits* of this kind of disorientation for a moment (which are real), the lack of context--of not even knowing where to start--is a great way of conceptualizing how your Nervous System feels when you've just been 'cracked' or manipulated/adjusted into a *suddenly* new position.â 
â 
With chiropractors seemingly everywhere, ready to manipulate your joints into a momentarily 'better' position (and momentarily relieve pain), we find ourselves gently reminding our clients (over and over) that *suddenly arriving* in a new place is not unequivically a GOOD thing.â 
â 
It CAN be a good thing, if that manipulation opens up the possibility for you to actively move your body in a way that was previously off-limits for you. But that hinges on you following up your adjustment with some *active inputs* (read: training that you do through the power of your own efforts, and not done TO you).â 
â 
But without that active follow-up component, the sudden change in context that a joint manipulation involves can be just as undermining to your autonomy as the pain you're trying to relieve.â 
â 
Now this is not a blanket condemnation of all chiros...in fact many of our colleagues are excellent chiro's who *mostly* teach their clients about how to play nice with their nervous systems, and use manipulations as a specific tool in their expansive toolbelts.â 
â 
But if you've been seeking pain relief in the form of getting your joints *cracked* into positions REPEATEDLY and over the LONG-TERM, consider learning how to actively control the positions of your joints. Basically, learn #ControlledArticularRotations or #CARs !â 
â 
In a very real sense, this IS the language of your body, at least from the first-person perspective.â 
â 
And knowing the language can completely change the experience of being in a new place ð.â 
â 
- Coach @welew_â 
â 

title:
Some #MovementSnax are more like dessert.

â¦if ice cold water and glorious views are your kind of dessert ð¤·ââï¸

But truly, I finally came to terms with my abbiding love for swimming in Random Bodies of Water this summer, and I remember the exact moment.

It was a hot evening in Wisconsin, in that same lake that I'm waterskiing on in the second vid aboveð

I was making my way from the dock out into the middle of the lake, where it was deep and clear of plants.

But where I started, by the dock, was thickly over-grown, with long vines snaking around my legs and lilypads poking me in the nose.

And for the first time in my life I was NOT grossed out. I was at peace with the fact that along with all those plants were innumerable little creatures that might wriggle and nip and suck onto me.

Just like they do over the rest of the Earth.

And just as *I* do.

WE are all the things that make up Earth; you and me, the lilypads and the leaches, the dirt, the trees, and the water.

The point is that movement is not merely something we do for fun, or to change ourselves, or to play a game. It's much more than that: it's how we interact with the physical world.

So each time I was able to submerge (or even dip a toe in) this summer, I did it. In Montana, Wisconsin, Wyoming, California and many other spots in between.

Each time, each place, it was a baptism by reality.

- Coach @welew_

I was verrrrry lucky to do a little international travel in July, and visit the Amalfi coast of Italy.

(Coach @HannahHusband here -- ciao!)

It reminded me that we always need a little more bandwidth than we planned for! 

That ridge that is silhouetted against the setting sun in the 2nd picture?

Yeah, we hiked out to the end of that peninsula, and down down down to a beautiful cove, where we swam in the clear aqua blue water with alllllllll the fishes. (vid 3)

The water was so cool, and there were so many incredible nooks to explore teaming with sea life, that we stayed later (and swam more) than we'd planned.

Then (womp womp) the hike back up was steeper than it looked on the way down, and it was HOT -- and we ran out of water less than half way up.

At that point, the only thing to do was to get back to the top, where we had more water in the car.

We adjusted our pace to go more slowly (especially so we could linger a little longer in the patches of shade along the trail).

Slowly, steadily, we made it.

It was a good reminder that a great adventure will often ask a bit more of your body than you thought.

I also remember thinking, while navigating the steepest rockiest most uneven "stairs" I've ever climbed (pic 4)â¦

âoh yeahhhhh THIS is why I do #Kinstretch!"
To give my joints a bit MORE range than they need in my every-day-life.

So that there's room for random.

So that I can say YES to the unknown.

As I reflect back on the recent Olympics, my thoughts continue to center around one athlete: Simone Biles.â 
â 
How extraordinary, and inspiring, it was to see a famous figure deliberately assert their need for *space*.â 
â 
Space from competing, from performing, from the expectations of others. And specifically--taking this space out of care for her own health.â 
â 
Because her health, something only she can be an expert in, is *important*.â 
â 
More important than medals, fame, or money.â 
â 
Even as the function of rest becomes more centered in our culture, there are still amazingly few examples of role models who publicly exhibit the specific hybrid of confidence and vulnerability that is true heroism.â 
â 
Simone Biles is a hero.â 
â 
And to see not just an Olympian, but a Truly Great Olympian, exhibit this kind of self-awareness and self-leadership simply stunned me.â 
â 
I'm not concerned with Simone's prodigious athletic ability, and surely not with the US Medal count ð... they both pale in importance to the power of Simone's act. #ReclaimingMyTimeâ 
