In June we started a new thang.

We decided to share with our members the "overall compliance rate", aka the percentage of workouts completed by the whole TFA membership team, as tracked in the app we use to deliver our people's personalized programs.

For some of us, it's hard to show up just for ourselves. 

So we wanted to remind our members that they are part of a team, and that their commitment to showing up for their bodies each week is buoyed by the efforts of their fellow Alchemists.

We also wanted to remind our community, and now you, that there are meaningful things to measure in fitness OTHER THAN the weight you lift, or the weight you see on the scale.

So many of us have been harmed by hyper-focusing on those kinds of metrics.

The most important thing to measure if you ask me? Showing up. Carving out some time in your day to check in with your body, and to offer some nourishing movement.

As a #RecoveringPerfectionist myself I would also like to remind us that 100% isn't the goal, and 38% is nothing to be ashamed of. There are going to be days or weeks when we can't attend to what we'd planned. 

Forgive yourself for what you missed. Re-invest in what matters to you. Start with the smallest bite that sounds tasty.

- Coach @hannahhusband

In order to learn, we have to fail.â 
â 
We have to figure out which parts are not working, or which strategies don't get us where we want to go.â 
â 
This is especially true when it comes to physical skills.â 
â 
Our bodies learn what works, and adapt to become stronger + more skillful, when they are bumping up against what doesn't work.â 
â 
For those of us #RecoveringPerfectionists -- this idea that failure should be an ongoing friend is very hard to swallow.â 
â 
But it's true! If we want to learn + grow, the best way we can do that is to dial in our practice so we are failing about 30% of the time.â 
â 
Not so much that it overwhelms or sidelines us, but juuuuuuust enough that we are learning about our edges.â 
â 
What might failing safely look like for you? â 
Could you invite in some room for mistakes?â 
â 

Injuries are never convenient.

Not when they happen, and interrupt your favorite ways of movingâ¦

And not when you are facing the journey back to function that your injured tissues need.

It can all seem so daunting.

But there is a decisive compoent that can make recovering from an injury not just possible butâdare I sayâ*empowering*?

Iâm talking about: SELF-KNOWLEDGE

...as in knowing what your body feels like, what it needs, how it can move and how it *can't* move (right now). Andâmost cruciallyâthe knowledge that you CAN change yourself.

Because armed with those things, you have equipped yourself to navigate the deep waters of *healing yourself*.

And without even delving into the more abstract ways that emotional and spirtual healing happens after an injury, the power of self-knowledge becomes real when you start making your CONTEXT work for you.

Like in the video above, taken as we flew down the highway in Arkansas.  @debbbbiee is giving her knee the inputs ( #ControlledArticularRotations ) it needs to come back into being the bona-fide KNEE that she wants and k-needs ð¤© , right from the passenger seat of the car.

Soundtrack is rockinâ too ð.

Because she knows how to give these inputs to HERSELF (and not only through the hands of a provider), Debbie is now able to guide her own tissue-adaptation process, wherever she might be.

So often, recovering from an injury makes us humans feel LESS capable and LESS trusting of our incredible, ever-adapting bodies, even if we eventually succeed at making the ouchie go away.

But when you can flip that script, and grab hold of the ways that you *can* guide your body into a version that works better for you--wherever you are--healing yourself becomes an exercise in empowerment.

Addressing your injured joints and tissue in this way is not just about the arrival point (HEALED) but actually is an opportunity to shift how you relate to your own biology.

- Coach @welew_
